[size=no report]

On 8 March 2021, students and parents demonstrated at the Ministry of Education in Khartoum (Khartoum state), after students with strong academic records were refused entry into public Universities. [size=no report]

On 7 March 2021, teachers began a sit-in demonstration in Kassala city (Kassala locality, Kassala state), in response to attempts by local authorities to transfer trade unionists (presumably to areas outside of Kassala). [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Police

On 6 March 2021, dozens of demonstrators gathered in several locations across Khartoum (Khartoum state) to protest against the arrival of the Egyptian President in the city that day. Police fired tear gas to disperse demonstrators, and made several arrests. [size=dozens]

Around 4 March 2021 (as reported), demonstrators - including students - gathered in Gereida (South Darfur state) denouncing the recent violence in the town. The demonstrators called for the perpetrators to be arrested, and for land rights and access to water to be resolved. [size=no report]

On 4 March 2021, an unknown group killed 5 South Sudanese refugees and wounded 4 others as they slept at the refugee camp in El Fula (El Salam locality, West Kordofan state). There is no further information regarding the identity of the attackers, nor their motivation.

On 4 March 2021, unknown militia forces attacked Daraba gold mine near Radom town (El Radoom locality, South Darfur state) for a second day, killing 5 miners and wounding 4 others (fatalities distributed across two events). Military forces have been deployed to mining areas in the locality.
On 4 March 2021, a honey farmer was shot and killed by unknown attackers at the forest near El Rahmania village (Abu Jubaiha locality, South Kordofan state). His brother escaped the attack.

Reports have emerged stating that two people were killed during the initial explosion (one of whom died of their wounds), with one of the inmates potentially being of foreign nationality.

On 3 March 2021, Fur and Tama groups clashed in Saraf Omra (North Darfur state), after several unspecified groups (including Fur groups) gathered to oppose the appointment of the new Sultan of the Tama. Around 3 March 2021 (as reported), farmers demonstrated in Tokar (Tokar locality, Red Sea state), calling for greater assistance for farmers on the part of local authorities; for a reduction in costs for irrigation; and for greater mechanization of farming. [size=no report]

On 3 March 2021, unknown militia forces attacked Daraba gold mine near Radom town (El Radoom locality, South Darfur state), killing 5 miners and wounding 4 others (fatalities distributed across two events). Military forces have been deployed to mining areas in the locality.

On 2 March 2021, students began a sit-in protest at Gedaref University (Gedaref locality, Gedaref state), calling for the Dean to resign due to the lack of action to improve University facilities. The protest has continued for at least 11 days. [size=no report]

On 2 March 2021, demonstrators gathered in Geissan town (Blue Nile state), calling for SAF to release the four people who had been detained since the previous day. On 1 March 2021, 14 gunmen on motorbikes attacked a gold mine at Hamra in the Hashaba area (Kutum locality, North Darfur state) [coded to Hashaba Center], firing shots in the air, before beating and robbing miners at the market at the mine.

The individuals were released the following day after demonstrations, though their money and produce (which they had intended to sell at the market) was confiscated by the soldiers.

Extensive looting and torching of dwellings was also reported. Unconfirmed reports suggest that militias from Chad were also involved in the violence.

actor1: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
notes: Agreement: On 31 December 2020, the mandate for the UNAMID peacekeeping force expired, and the planned (phased) drawdown of peacekeepers and infrastructure began. Peacekeeping patrols are also to finish. The mission will be replaced with the United Nations Integrated Transition Assistance Mission, which will focus on mediation, peacebuilding and providing assistance to transitional authorities in Khartoum, as responsibility for security in Darfur is transferred to state forces. The withdrawal has sparked demonstrations in several IDP camps in Darfur, with the region continuing to experience recurrent violence, albeit at lower levels than at the height of the war in Darfur.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 18 December 2020, men in SAF and RSF uniforms (and coded as such) shot and wounded a pastoralist at Bogaya village 15km south of Dilling town (South Kordofan state) [coded to Abu Seba]. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 17 December 2020, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer who had attempted to clear them from his land in the Um Lamina area near Hamra in Kutum locality (North Darfur state) [coded to Hamra]. Two of the attackers were subsequently arrested.
On 17 December 2020, a man was arrested and tortured by police in Omdurman (Umm Badda, Khartoum), and was released on 25 December. The victim died of his injuries shortly after release.
On 17 December 2020, a pastoralist was killed and his body mutilated at Tema close to Wali in Dilling locality (South Kordofan state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Movement of forces: Around 17 December 2020, a mass deployment of Sudanese Armed Forces and Rapid Support Forces paramilitaries was reported in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Jebel Alokdi]. Reinforcements have arrived in response to clashes with Amhara regional security forces and militia in disputed areas along the Ethiopian border, with food and financial support provided by members of the Beni Amir and al-Habab clan.
On 17 December 2020, hundreds of former soldiers who had been retired during the Omar al Bashir era protested at the army HQ in Khartoum, calling for their reinstatement in the army. [size=hundreds]

On 16 December 2020, unknown attackers clashed with a militia in the Wali area of Dilling locality (South Kordofan state) [coded to Wali] after the attackers attempted to steal cattle. Two were injured in the fighting (one seriously).

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 16 December 2020, an RSF paramilitaries shot and killed a student travelling between El Tina and Karnoi in El Tina locality (North Darfur state) [coded to Basaso]. A relative of the victim said the soldiers were attempting to rob the student.

On 16 December 2020, farmers closed the road between Kutum and El Fasher (through unspecified means) in the Hamra area of Kutum locality (North Darfur state) [coded to Hamra]. The farmers were demonstrating against the intrusion of pastoralists and livestock onto their farms, and threatening behavior from pastoralists. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 16 December 2020, men in SAF and RSF uniforms (and coded as such) attacked farmers at Bogaya village 15km south of Dilling town (South Kordofan state) [coded to Abu Seba], wounding two. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 16 December 2020, armed pastoralists shot and wounded a young pastoralist in the area of Baboya (approximate coordinates from humanitarian map used) in Dilling locality (South Kordofan state) [coded to Baboya], after he objected to attempts by the pastoralists to establish a cattle pen at the village.

On 16 December 2020, market vendors protested in Dilling (Dilling, South Kordofan state) after a colleague was arrested by GIS agents. The demonstrators were also objecting to a 300 per cent increase in the rate of taxation for consumer goods. [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
source: Sudan News Agency; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 15 December 2020, SAF soldiers were ambushed by Ethiopian armed forces (presumed to be Amhara Liyu Police) and Amhara militia in the area of Jebel Abu Tiyour (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state). Unconfirmed reports suggest 4 or 5 were killed and 27 wounded on the Sudanese side, and soldiers and military vehicles captured; there is no information on Ethiopia casualties. Ethiopian forces were reported to have shelled Sudanese forces.

actor2: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
source: Sudan Tribune; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan News Agency
notes: On 15 December 2020, SAF clashed with Ethiopian armed forces (likely belonging to the Amhara Liyu Police) and Amhara militia in the area of El Usra in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Hamid Wad Uthman]. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

actor2: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
source: Sudan News Agency; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 15 December 2020, SAF clashed with Ethiopian armed forces (likely belonging to the Amhara regional security forces) and Amhara militia in the area of Mashra Wad Arud (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state). There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

Agreement: On 14 December 2020, and following a lengthy process of negotiations, the US government has removed Sudan from its list of State Sponsors of Terrorism (SST). The removal of the SST designation completes the normalization of relations with the US, and has required Sudan to pay $335 million in compensation claims (likely paid by another country or countries, given Sudan's economic situation). The IMF has indicated that debt relief and restructuring will commence, though only once Sudan clears its arrears with various international financial institutions (which will likely be paid for by the US). Normalization of relations with Israel has also been a precondition of the deal.

On 14 December 2020, members of the Misseriya ethnic group began a sit-in protest at the Abyei Supervisory Administrative office in Khartoum, calling for the dismissal of the Sudanese head of the office to be dismissed and for greater representation of Misseriya in the administration of the disputed area. [size=no report]

Around 14 December 2020 (as reported), protesters from Eastern Sudan demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for injustices relating to the 2005 Port Sudan massacre and the recent violence in Kassala and Red Sea states to be rectified. [size=no report]

On 13 December 2020, striking doctors protested at the state Ministry of Health in Nyala (Nyala, South Darfur state). The source does not specify details about the reason for the strike, though previous protests involving health workers in Nyala have been directed against poor working conditions. [size=no report]

Around 13 December 2020 (as reported), demonstrators gathered in the neighborhood of Al Fitahab in Omdurman (Umm Badda, Khartoum state), as part of a dispute regarding housing and land. [size=no report]

On 13 December 2020, dock workers protested in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea state), in anti-privatization protests. The demonstrators are calling for the appointment of the former director as a consultant to be reversed. [size=no report]

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
actor2: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
notes: On 12 December 2020, SLM/A Nur rebels claimed they were attacked by a splinter faction of the group (which they say has defected to the government) under the command of Zunoon Abdelshafi, who were allegedly operating alongside RSF paramilitaries. The fighting occurred in the Dori area of Jebel Marrah, though it is unclear which locality of the area Dori is located in [coded to Jebel Marrah]. The rebels claimed to have inflicted a ''heavy loss of lives'' against the attackers, and to have killed a Major in the RSF. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

On 12 December 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Kebkabiya (Kebkabiya, North Darfur state), calling for the UN Mission in Darfur to remain in operation in the area, and not to hand over security responsibilities to state security organs. [size=no report]

On 12 December 2020, demonstrators - including activists and members of unspecified civil society organizations - gathered at the US embassy in Khartoum, to protest US involvement in Sudanese politics, and delays at removing the state sponsor of terrorism designation. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-); Labour Group (Sudan)
notes: On 12 December 2020, seven armed men on camels (and coded as a Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked a commercial vehicle near Dobo Umda in Tawila locality (North Darfur state), killing a soldier travelling on the vehicle (and presumed to be off-duty) and wounding two other passengers. There is no clear motive for the attack.
On 11 December 2020, a woman was abducted by unidentified gunmen near Katur in Tawila locality (North Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 11 December 2020, a local official was abducted and severely beaten by an unknown group (presumed to be a pastoralist militia) from Belle el-Sereif in Sharg Jabel Marra locality (South Darfur state). The attackers are demanding the release of a camel which had been confiscated from them. The victim remains in captivity.

On 11 December 2020, Ethiopian Amhara militia shot and killed a Sudanese farmer at an unspecified location north of El Galabat town in Eastern El Galabat locality (Gedaref state) close to the Atbara river [coded to Mashra Tuklayn]. There is no clear motive for the attack, which comes amid escalating violence and abductions in the area.

Around 10 December 2020, unknown gunmen attacked Belle el-Sereif in Sharg Jabel Marra locality (South Darfur state), beating civilians (with one source saying that a civilian was shot dead by the group; note that this is not confirmed in the other source) and abducting the chief administrator of the village. One source says the attackers were demanding money for items they claimed had been stolen from them.

Around 10 December 2020 (as reported), Resistance Committees began a sit-in protest in Omdurman (Umm Badda, Khartoum), after the governor of Khartoum state refused to meet with them to discuss problems (which are not specified in the source). [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 10 December 2020, RSF paramilitaries clashed with an armed group (wearing SAF and RSF uniforms, and coded as such) who were attempting to rob the Ukrainian embassy in Khartoum. In the firefight that followed several injuries were reported, and a number of arrests made. The RSF spokesman has claimed the soldiers who were looting the embassy were impersonating military and paramilitary personnel.

On 9 December 2020, striking workers at the Sea Port Authority demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), blocking the entrance way to the southern port with shipping containers. The strikes follows an attempt to appoint an executive director (whose appointment was viewed as making privatization of the port more likely); the appointment was swiftly reversed after the strike. [size=no report]

Around 8 December 2020, precariously employed and seasonal workers at the sugar plant in Asalaya in El Jabalian locality (White Nile state) began a sit-in protest, calling for permanent contracts. [size=no report]

On 8 December 2020, Misseriya youth demonstrated at the UNISFA base at Todach in the disputed Abyei PCA area, blocking the entrance to the facility (through unspecified means). The youth were demanding that UNISFA and contractors employ youths from their community. The youth left after engagement from the base commander. [size=no report]

On 7 December 2020, thousands of IDPs demonstrated in Kalma IDP Camp in Nyala locality (South Darfur state), calling for UNAMID to remain in Darfur, amid fears of abuses by government forces in the event peacekeepers leave. The demonstrators have begun a sit-in protest. [size=thousands]

Around 7 December 2020 (as reported), protesters gathered in Al Korda village in El Matammah locality (River Nile state) and began a sit-in protest to denounce scarcities of flour and fuel, and the absence of effective government services in the area. [size=no report]

On 7 December 2020, outlawed PDF paramilitaries attacked a bus at an unspecified area described as being 30km north-east of El Abassiya town (South Kordofan state) along the road to Kosti [coded to El Fakharin]. The bus driver was shot dead, and the passengers beaten and robbed. Police have refused to investigate.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
actor2: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
notes: On 5 December 2020, two unspecified factions of the SLM/A-Nur rebel group (at least one of whom is presumed to be a splinter group) clashed in the Nimra area near Suni in Sharg Jabel Marra locality (South Darfur state). Two children were killed and a third was wounded in the crossfire; the source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities among the clashing rebel factions.

On 3 December 2020, Chadian Zaghawa militia attacked Sudanese pastoralists at an unspecified location along the Sudan-Chad border, likely to be in northern El Geneina locality or southern Sirba locality in West Darfur state [coded to Tendelti]. The attack, which killed one pastoralist and wounded three, is linked to violence earlier that week in the Tendelti area.

Movement of forces: Around 2 December 2020 (as reported), the Sudanese army announced that it had moved into several disputed parts of El Fashaga and Eastern El Gallabat localities along the Ethiopian border in Gedaref state [coded to Jebel Alokdi]. Subsequent information suggests SAF moved into these areas on or after 6 November, following the outbreak of hostilities in Tigray. Lt. Gen. Al Burhan has claimed that this had been agreed with Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed on 1 November.

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
notes: On 2 December 2020, an unspecified armed group clashed with UNISFA peacekeepers close to Doungab in the disputed Abyei PCA area (approximate coordinates based on UNISFA map used at GP2), after the armed group fired upon the peacekeepers. No casualties were reported.

Around 2 December 2020 (as reported), hundreds of retired army veterans demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for financial compensation to be paid in lieu of unpaid benefits, injuries sustained during service, and for unfair dismissal. [size=hundreds]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 2 December 2020, two farmers were killed and a third wounded by RSF paramilitaries near Elefain in Kadugli locality (South Kordofan state), after the farmers had earlier cleared cattle from their farmland. Authorities have failed to investigate the attack.

Around 1 December 2020 (as reported), armed pastoralists attacked farmers at an unspecified location in northern Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state) [coded to Birkat Seira], wounding three. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 1 December 2020, Chadian gunmen identified as being from the Zaghawa ethnic group clashed with Sudanese pastoralists near Tendelti (West Darfur state) (note that there are two locations with this name close to each other in Sirba and El Geneina localities; event presumed to have taken place in El Geneina locality due to its close proximity to the border), killing two and wounding two (one seriously). The attack appears to relate to stolen cattle.

On 30 November 2020, chiefs from the Beja ethnic group demonstrated against the Juba peace agreement in Khartoum, and reiterated demands for self-determination of Eastern Sudan made at the Sinkat conference several months ago. [size=no report]

Around 29 November 2020, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer close to Birkat Seira in Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), after the farmer attempted to clear them from his land. Note that one source describes the attackers as armed robbers, who returned to kill the victim after he initially fended them off.

On 29 November 2020, dozens of demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for the release of prisoners detained since January during unrest in the state, and for accountability for those they accuse of torturing the detainees. [size=dozens]

Around 29 November 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) began a sit-in protest in Bout in Al Tadamon locality (Blue Nile state), calling for a range of improvements to water and transportation infrastructure; health and education services; employment opportunities; and for the end of invasive security measures. [size=no report]

Around 29 November 2020, members of the Revolutionary Alliance for Eastern Sudan protested in Kassala (Kassala state), denouncing the killing of 8 Beni Amir during demonstrations in October and calling for justice for the deaths. The demonstrators are presumed to be largely from the Beni Amir ethnic group. [size=no report]

On 28 November 2020, members of a paramilitary group described as the ''Reserve Force'' (note that this is either referring to the Abu Tira/Central Reserve Police paramilitary group, or to SAF reservists. Actor1 provisionally coded as SAF) clashed with Ethiopian Amhara militiamen who had abducted five Sudanese farmers. The clash took place in or near Kenin area along the border with Ethiopia (presumed to be an alternative spelling of Keneina, Basundah locality, Gedaref state), and the abductees were released. The report does not mention whether there were fatalities or casualties.

On 26 November 2020, six armed men intercepted travelers on a commercial vehicle in the El-Baida area approximately 20km west of Kalogi town on the road to Talodi (South Kordofan state) [coded to Tozi]. The attackers fired at the vehicle after the driver refused to stop, wounding one of the passengers. One source links an increase in such events to tensions between Kenana Arifab and Hawazma Dar Ali clans.

On 26 November 2020, owners of gas distribution centers in El Obeid gathered in protest in front of the government secretariat in El Obeid (Shiekan, North Kordofan State), calling on the government to redistribute gas across their centers as the current distributions negatively affected their salaries. [size=no report]

On 26 November 2020, around 1000 people protested in front of public prosecutors at an unidentified location in South Darfur to demand the immediate release of Musa Hilal, the head of the Revolutionary Awakening Council who has been detained for more than 3 years. [size=around 1000]

On 26 November 2020, around 1000 people protested in front of public prosecutors at an unidentified location in North Darfur to demand the immediate release of Musa Hilal, the head of the Revolutionary Awakening Council who has been detained for more than 3 years. [size=around 1000]

On 25 November 2020, Ethiopian Amhara militiamen abducted five Sudanese farmers from the Kenin area along the border with Ethiopia (presumed to be an alternative spelling of Keneina, Basundah locality, Gedaref state). The captors demanded a ransom payment for their return. One source reports 2 farmers were killed and the wounding of an unspecified number of others, though it is not clear whether this took place during the abduction or whilst the abductees were in captivity.

On 25 November 2020, protesters gathered in front of the governor's house in El Fasher (El Fasher, North Darfur State) to protest the killing of 2 civilians by unidentified gunmen in Tawila that week. [size=no report]

On 24 November 2020, dozens of workers from the Ministry of Infrastructure and Urban Development protested in El Fasher (El Fasher, North Darfur State) calling for the dismissal of the director general, accused of corruption. [size=dozens]

source: Al Rakoba; Ayin Network; Radio Dabanga
notes: On 24 November 2020, gunmen from an unidentified armed group shot and killed a farmer and his son near Mertal village in Tawila locality (North Darfur state) for unknown reasons.
On 24 November 2020, three men dressed in military uniforms from an unidentified armed group shot and killed a farmer near Nertiti (Central Darfur State) and stole his belongings.
On 23 November 2020, gunmen belonging to an unidentified armed group shot and killed a civilian in Umtajok (Kreinik, West Darfur State).

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Looting: On 22 November 2020, men in RSF paramilitary uniform (and coded as such) intercepted and robbed travelers in the Gardood Torro area, approximately 20km west of Kalogi town on the road to Talodi (South Kordofan state) [coded to Tozi]. One source links an increase in such events to tensions between Kenana Arifab and Hawazma Dar Ali clans.
On 21 November 2020, SAF personnel were seen beating Ethiopian refugees at Village 8 in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state), after the refugees took food before it could be officially distributed.

Around 21 November 2020 (as reported), unspecified security forces (presumed to be SAF pending further information) attacked a convoy of 10 vehicles smuggling subsidized goods into Eritrea at an unspecified location in Kassala locality (Kassala state) [coded to Abu Gamal]. In the firefight, a prominent smuggler was wounded and later died in Kassala hospital from blood loss. Smuggling has reportedly increased after Eritrean border forces have been redeployed due to ongoing military activity in Tigray.

On 19 November 2020, members of the Batahin and Kawahala ethnic groups clashed in Abu Delelq town in Sharq El Nile locality (Khartoum state), reportedly after a member of the Kawahala was appointed to a leadership position in the town. An unspecified number were injured the clash.
Around 18 November 2020 (as reported), farmers protested in Ed Damer (River Nile state), calling for increased supplies of fuel prior to the upcoming harvest. [size=no report]

On 15 November 2020, members of the Beja ethnic group closed the Port Sudan-Khartoum highway in the Haya area (Red Sea state) through unspecified means, in protest against the Juba peace agreement. [size=no report]

On 15 November 2020, armed pastoralists clashed with farmers at an unspecified area in Habila locality (West Darfur state), after livestock entered farmland. Police intervened on the side of the farmers. One farmer was killed and two wounded, whilst a pastoralist and a police officer were also wounded. Two pastoralist were arrested.

On 13 November 2020, unknown attackers (reported to be linked to the deposed regime of Omar el Bashir, and presumed to be members of the disbanded PDF militiamen, given their presence in South Kordofan) attacked a vehicle north of Dibebad in Al Qoz locality (South Kordofan state) on the road to El Obeid. An engineer was killed in the attack, and several others wounded. There is no clear motive.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
assoc_actor_2: SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction)
notes: On 13 November 2020, SLM/A al Nur supporters armed with firearms and bladed weapons attacked a meeting of the SLM/A TC faction in the Hajj Yusuf suburb of Khartoum, whilst the faction was holding an outreach meeting on the Juba peace agreement. The TC claimed that around 30 were wounded, including two senior officials. There is no clear motive for the attack.
On 12 November 2020, residents of a Port Sudan suburb demonstrated against shortages of water in the area. [size=no report]

Around 12 November 2020 (as reported), bakery owners demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the public to desist from blaming them for high bread prices (which increased following the recent reduction of flour subsidies). [size=no report]

On 12 November 2020, dozens (one report says hundreds) of IDPs from Zamzam camp blocked the road with burning tires and barricades at an unspecified location along the road between Nyala and El Fasher (North Darfur state) [coded to Zamzam]. The IDPs denounced deteriorating conditions in the camp, and WFP plans to begin withdrawing food aid. [size=dozens]
On 12 November 2020, employees from a teachers union demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for salary arrears to be paid, and for the pay system to be overhauled. [size=no report]

On 11 November 2020, members of the Revolutionary Alliance for Eastern Sudan protested in the market in Kassala, denouncing the killing of 8 Beni Amir during demonstrations in October, and calling for the dismissal of senior political and security elites from the state, as well as an end to ethnic bias in job appointments. The demonstrators are presumed to be largely from the Beni Amir ethnic group. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Around 11 November 2020 (week of), RSF paramilitaries arrested three civilians in El Sireaf locality and detained them at the RSF base in Kebkabiya ( Kebkabiya, North Darfur state), where at least one of them was beaten. A relative suggests an RSF captain detained them over mining work he claims to have contracted them for.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Mass grave: Around 11 November 2020 (as reported), the discovery of a mass grave in Khartoum was announced, which contained bodies of missing victims from the RSF-led massacre from 3 June 2019. The number of bodies in the grave is not specified.
On 11 November 2020, xenophobic protests were reported in central Khartoum, which are implied to have been directed against Ethiopians. There is no further information on the event. [size=no report]
On 10 November 2020, residents of Zalingei (Central Darfur state) blocked a bridge in the city (through unspecified means) in protest at deteriorating security in the area. [size=no report]

On 9 November 2020, supporters of Musa Hilal's RAC demonstrated in Saraf Omra town (North Darfur state), calling for his release and the release of other members who been detained by authorities. [size=no report]

On 9 November 2020, gunmen reported to be affiliated to the outlawed NCP fired pistols against the building housing the anti-corruption committee in Singa (Sennar state). Police fired tear gas against the gunmen, and made several arrests.

Around 9 November 2020 (as reported), dozens of Ethiopian refugees demonstrated in Khartoum, against the decision to reclassify them as asylum seekers rather than refugees, which the refugees fear will prevent them working, undertaking educational exams, or receiving subsidized bread. [size=dozens]

Around 9 November 2020 (as reported), dozens of demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) demonstrated at Khartoum Teaching Hospital in the capital, calling for the proposed transfer of the emergency department in the hospital to Khartoum state to be reversed. The protest appears to be linked to concerns about the administration of hospitals under the deposed al-Bashir regime. [size=dozens]

On 8 November 2020, dozens of teachers demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the director at the state ministry for education to remain in office, and for the abolition of quotas to assign positions in the state government. [size=dozens]
On 8 November 2020, protesters (including Resistance Committee members) demonstrated against poor services and high electricity costs in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). [size=no report]

On 8 November 2020, IDPs from Zamzam camp began a sit-in protest at the WFP office in El Fasher (North Darfur state), after the organization announced a change in food distribution to IDPs, meaning some receive continuous aid, others temporary aid, and those deemed not to be in need of aid having aid withdrawn. [size=no report]

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
actor2: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
notes: On 8 November 2020, SLM/A Nur rebels clashed once again with a splinter faction of the group led by Zunoon Abdelshafi at Sabi in Tawila locality (Central Darfur state) for unclear reasons. A large number of civilians have been displaced from the area. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

actor1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: Non-violent activity: On 7 November 2020, the Sudanese Communist Party withdrew from the FFC alliance, which currently represents civilian political forces in the transitional government. The withdrawal decisively shifts the balance of power to conservative groups in the FFC, after the Sudanese Professionals Association withdrew in August, and further fractures the FFC. The Communist Party has (alongside the SPA) moved closer to the SPLM-N al-Hilu rebel group, and have denounced what they describe as the increasingly close relationship between the FFC and the military, as well as the removal of subsidies under IMF guidance.

On 7 November 2020, unknown gunmen fired upon a vehicle close to Abdel Shakur in Kutum locality (North Darfur state), killing a passenger and seriously wounding the driver. There is no clear motive for the attack.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
notes: Weapons seizure: Around 7 November 2020 (as reported), Sudanese Military Intelligence seized 95,000 rounds of ammunition which smugglers were attempting to bring into Ethiopia. The interception took place at an unspecified village along the Ethiopian border in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Safarah].

Around 7 November 2020 (between 6 - 9 November), Ethiopian officials accused Sudanese forces of attacking settlements inhabited by Amhara farmers at unspecified locations in disputed areas east of the Atbara river in Gedaref state [coded to Mashra Wad Arud]. SAF are accused of looting and burning farms, and killing an unspecified number of Amhara (unknown fatalities coded as 3). 400 to 500 households are reported to have been displaced from early November to late December (after a Sudanese military offensive began in mid-December). Satellite imagery shows fields having been torched in areas around Wad Arud and Wad Kholy.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
actor2: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
notes: On 7 November 2020, SLM/A Nur rebels clashed a splinter faction of the group led by Zunoon Abdelshafi at Sabi in Tawila locality (Central Darfur state) for unclear reasons. SLM/A Nur loyalists claimed to have repulsed the attack, and alleged that the security services were involved in coordinating the attack, which has been denied by authorities. A large number of civilians have been displaced from the area. There is no information on casualties or fatalities.

On 6 November 2020, armed pastoralists from northern South Kordofan state attacked Tagali farmers at Al-Jebailat village in Abu Kershola locality (South Kordofan state) [coded to Abu Kershola], wounding one. The farmers had been attempting to clear the pastoralists from their land.

On 6 November 2020, three Sudanese pastoralists were abducted by a Chadian militia at an unspecified location (implied to be in El Geneina locality, West Darfur state) [coded to Dumej] and taken into Chad along with 86 head of cattle. The abduction is in revenge for the murder of a Chadian civilian.

On 5 November 2020, dozens of Sudanese Forces for Change (an alliance of very small rebel groups, which is part of the broader Sudan Revolutionary Front coalition) supporters protested in Khartoum after their group's offices were stormed by General Intelligence Services agents, and several leaders detained. [size=dozens]

source: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Sudan News Agency
notes: Non-violent activity: On 5 November 2020, Sudanese authorities closed the borders with Ethiopia in Kassala and Gedaref states, following the crisis in Tigray. Two brigades of the army have been deployed at unspecified locations along the border.
On 4 November 2020, an Amhara militia attacked Sudanese farmers at Keneina (Basundah locality, Gedaref state), killing 1 and wounding 3, 200 head of cattle were also stolen.

On 4 November 2020, medical students began a sit-in protest at the University of Nyala in Nyala city (South Darfur state), calling for an end to use of visiting academics in favor of employing permanent staff, and for fixed timetables for the school year to be established. [size=no report]
On 3 November 2020, hundreds of demonstrators protested at the army HQ in Khartoum, demanding justice for those killed in the massacre of 3 June 2019. [size=hundreds]

On 1 November 2020, dozens of demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched in Khartoum, calling for the results of overdue official investigation into the 3 June 2019 massacre to be released. Upon arriving at the investigating committee building, activists discovered it was no longer in use by the committee, leading to new demands for the current location of the committee to be disclosed. Unspecified security forces (coded as police) arrested at least one Resistance Committee member, who was badly beaten whilst in detention, and had his head forcibly shaved. [size=dozens]

On 1 November 2020, demonstrators (including Resistance Committee members) marched in Atbara (River Nile state), denouncing shortages of bread and fuel and the lack of affordable transportation. [size=no report]

On 1 November 2020, primary and secondary students demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), denouncing the lack of bread and affordable transportation in the city, and demanding the provision of basic services. [size=no report]

Around 1 November 2020 (as reported), workers at the sugar plant in Ad Douiem (White Nile state) began a sit-in demonstration, calling for the dismissal of officials linked the Bashir regime; for job losses to be averted; and for increases in salaries. [size=no report]
On 31 October 2020, residents of Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) were reported to have rioted in the city, as part of demonstrations against the removal of subsidies of fuel. [size=no report]

On 30 October 2020, heavy clashes between pastoralists from the the Hawazmah branch of the Baggara and pastoralists of the Kenana ethnic group were reported close to Gadier in Talodi locality (South Kordofan state), reportedly linked to disputes over access to grazing routes. There is no currently no information regarding fatalities or casualties.
On 30 October 2020, demonstrations started outside several mosques in Khartoum following Friday prayer, with anti-French chants and the burning of Israeli flags taking place. [size=no report]

On 29 October 2020, demonstrators blocked the road (through unspecified means) from Galabat to Gedaref at the El Hamra area Eastern El Galabat locality [coded to Humra] in protest at the killing of a farmer (in suspected tribal clashes) in El Hamra. [size=no report]
On 29 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators protested in Khartoum against the doubling of fuel prices, which was introduced by the government two days prior. [size=thousands]

On 28 October 2020, 'limited' protests took place in Khartoum against the doubling of fuel prices, which was introduced by the government the previous day. Motorists blocked two bridges using their cars in protest at the increase. [size=limited]

Around 28 October 2020, a farmer was killed by unknown attackers in the El Hamra area of Eastern El Galabat locality (Gedaref state, location presumed to be an alternative spelling of Humra). The source suggests the killing may be linked to tensions between the Hausa and El Lahwi groups in the area, which previously resulted in violence in mid-2018.

On 28 October 2020, Resistance Committee members demonstrated at the office of the public prosecutor in Khartoum, calling for the release of their fellow activists who have been detained by RSF paramilitaries. [size=no report]

Around 27 October 2020, an Amhara militia killed two Sudanese farmers at an unspecified area between Taya and Basanga (potentially an alternative spelling of Basundah) in Basundah locality (Gedaref state), and abducted two others for ransom. The attacks come in the context of tensions over farmland in the disputed border area.

On 27 October 2020, residents of Joda in El Jebalain locality (White Nile state) next to the South Sudanese border began a sit-in protest following the signing of trade agreements between Sudan and South Sudan. The demonstrators are calling for the common market to be on the Sudanese side of the border; for improvements to infrastructure and services in the area; and for there to be no interference in economic activities from security forces, including the removal of checkpoints. [size=no report]

On 27 October 2020, dozens of female IDPs demonstrated at the UNAMID HQ in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for an end to the marginalization of women, and particularly displaced women. The protest coincides with the visit of senior UN and AU officials to the city. [size=dozens]

On 27 October 2020, 'limited' protests took place in Atbara against the doubling of fuel prices, which was introduced by the government on the same day. [size=limited]

Around 26 October 2020 (as reported), workers from the water and electricity authorities in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) began a sit-in demonstration in protest at poor working conditions, low pay, and job insecurity. [size=no report]

On 26 October 2020, striking workers from the Saving and Social Development Bank demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for improvements to working conditions, and the restructuring of the senior levels of the organization. The director of the bank has since been removed. [size=no report]

Around 25 October 2020, a journalist was abducted by men in military uniform (and coded as such) outside the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Khartoum. The attackers beat the journalist, and then robbed him.

On 25 October 2020, dismissed workers from Sudan Airways demonstrated in Khartoum, before beginning a sit-in protest. The director of the firm agreed to reinstate the dismissed employees the following week. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, demonstrators described as 'victims of the Gulf war' (presumed to be military veterans) began a sit-in protest at the UN building in Khartoum, calling for benefits to be paid. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, hundreds of activists (including Resistance Committee members) demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the release of nine activists accused of murdering an RSF paramilitary during the June 3rd massacre. [size=hundreds]

On 23 October 2020, demonstrators gathered in several areas of Khartoum to denounce efforts by the executive to normalize relations with Israel. Some demonstrators burned Israeli flags. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, 50 gunmen on camel and horseback attacked the village of Sabrelwagiha (described as being 30km south of Gereida; coordinates for Haddad used at GP2), killing 2. There has been intense violence involving attacks by Fellata pastoralists against Masalit civilians in the area this past week, and this event is presumed to involve the same actors.

assoc_actor_1: SPA: Sudan Professionals Association; Resistance Committees (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Labour Group (Sudan); Journalists (Sudan)
source: Radio Dabanga; Ayin Network; Al Jazeera
notes: On 21 October 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Khartoum to commemorate the 1964 October Revolution. Demonstrators included FFC supports, who appear to have been demonstrating separately from SPA supporters and Resistance Committee members. The demonstrators called for a correction in the course of the uprising, amid increasing dissatisfaction with the progress made towards reforming political institutions and reversing economic decline. The demonstrators burned tires and placed bricks in the road. Police fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, whilst a number journalists covering the events were assaulted by police. [size=thousands]

The demonstrators also called for an end to violence in the East of Sudan. [size=thousands]

On 21 October 2020, supporters of the outlawed NCP demonstrated against the transitional government in Khartoum. There have been allegations that participants were paid to attend the demonstrations. [size=no report]

Some demonstrators threw stones at police, leading the police to disperse the demonstrators, and make a number of arrests (including of the senior NCP member). [size=no report]

Around 21 October 2020, Fellata pastoralists attacked several Masalit settlements and IDP camps in Gereida locality, including Haddad, Ed Dekka, Donkey Abyad, Um Asal and Um Zagrad. At least 13 were killed (some of whom died later of their injuries) in the attacks which took place on 20 and 21 October, and 28 were wounded. Around 4,850 families were displaced in the attacks, and at least 200 dwellings were torched. Two events coded for 20 and 21 October in Haddad and Gereida, with fatalities spread evenly across both.

On 18 October 2020, dozens of Eastern Sudanese protesters marched in Khartoum, denouncing killings by state forces in Kassala on October 15. On 18 October 2020, clashes were reported once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), amid ethnicised violence between the Beni Amir and Beja groups. An official has said that nobody was killed during the clashes, though the report does not mention whether there were injuries.

On 17 October 2020, medical students demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), calling for improvements in studying conditions and the removal of the head of the medicine department at the University of Nyala. [size=no report]

On 17 October 2020, clashes were reported once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), killing four and wounding five, amid ethnicised violence between the Beni Amir and Beja groups. At least one civilian was among the wounded. A hospital in the city was also attacked by an unspecified group.
Around 17 October 2020 (as reported), protesters gathered in Khartoum to denounce excessive violence used by security forces against demonstrators in Kassala. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, clashes were reported once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), amid ethnicised violence between the Beni Amir and Beja groups. 3 individuals died the following weekend as a result of violence in Port Sudan, which also took place on 14 October. On 16 October 2020, thousands of Beni Amir mourners demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state), denouncing the killing of demonstrators the previous day. [size=thousands]

Eight were killed and at least 30 wounded, with two reports saying a member of the police was among the dead. Dozens were arrested. Three fatalities evenly distributed across both events.

[size=no report]

On 14 October 2020, supporters of the recently dismissed governor of Kassala state (and presumed to be Beni Amir) once again demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state). Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, Prime Minister Hamdock fired Saleh Ammar, the Beni Amir Governor of Kassala, amid deteriorating security in East Sudan. The Governor refused to resign, prompting his dismissal. The appointment of the Governor in July exacerbated tensions among the Beni Amir and Beja clans in the East.

On 13 October 2020, an Amhara militia abducted six women and one child from farms near El Leya (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state) [coded to Um Tawakkul], and have since demanded a ransom for their return. The abductions follow renewed attacks by Ethiopian irregulars the previous week.
On 13 October 2020, Beni Amir demonstrators blocked roads in Kassala (Kassala state) with burning tires, to denounce the firing of the Governor of the state that same day. [size=no report]
Around 13 October 2020 (as reported), two pastoralists were found dead near Bir Saleeba north of El Geneina (West Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 11 October 2020, civil servants demonstrated in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), calling for promotions, and arguing there has been unequal treatment of employees with regards to job progression. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_2: SPLM-N-Agar: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Malik Agar faction); SLM/A-Minnawi: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Minnawi Faction); SLM/A-Transitional Council: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Transitional Council Faction); JEM: Justice and Equality Movement
source: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Radio Tamazuj
notes: On 31 August 2020, the Sudanese government signed a series of eight distinct agreements (which cumulatively form a comprehensive peace agreement) in Juba, South Sudan. The agreements include a set of changes to administrative structures, and outline military and political power-sharing provisions, with specific economic and security arrangements for certain areas. The agreements were signed by members of the SRF umbrella group (including JEM, SPLM-N Agar faction, and SLM/A-TC) along with SLM/A Minawi rebels. The two major rebel groups - SLM/A al-Nur, and SPLM-N al-Hilu (a.k.a. Nuba Mountains faction) - did not sign the agreement. On 3 September, PM Hamdock signed a separate declaration of principles with Abdelaziz al-Hilu in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, paving the way for future talks.

On 30 August 2020, pastoralists demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for peace, neutral security forces to uphold security, and for displaced persons to be allowed to return to their home areas and be provided with surfaces. [size=no report]

source: Radio Dabanga; UNOCHA; VOA; Ayin Network

The demonstrators also called for a restructuring of the FFC, and for the security forces to relinquish control of businesses. Police and unknown men in civilian attire attacked protesters with batons and tear gas, wounding an unspecified number, and arresting 77. The newly rebranded intelligence forces have denied their agents were the men in civilian attire. [size=thousands]

On 16 August 2020, demonstrators gathered at an unspecified location in Karai locality (Khartoum state), calling for the removal of the locality director and corrupt officials, and improvements in waste management. The demonstrators began a sit-in protest that has lasted at least 5 days. [size=no report]

On 14 August 2020, unspecified security forces (presumed to be police) arrested a large number of activists as well as residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state), with at least four being tortured during detention.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change

source: Radio Dabanga; AP; Reuters; Sudan Tribune; VOA
notes: On 13 August 2020, clashes between members of the Beni Amir and Nuba continued, with at least 35 killed (one of whom died later of their wounds) and 123 injured (including at least some soldiers) across five days of fighting in Port Sudan, and at least 85 have been arrested. Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days. Looting has been reported in the aftermath of the clashes.

Around 12 August 2020 (as reported), an Amhara militia attacked an unspecified location along the Sudanese-Ethiopian border in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Barakhat], stealing 9,000 sheep, camels and cows, and killing an unspecified number of farmers in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

source: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; VOA; AP; Reuters

Homes and shops have been torched. Fatalities distributed across five events to conform to death toll reported across the first three days of fighting, with remaining fatalities split evenly across the fourth and fifth days.

On 9 August 2020, SSPDF allegedly attacked the Ngok Dinka village of Goli (Abyei), killing three (including a child) and wounding three. Two soldiers of their own were lost during fighting. There is no clear motive for the attack.

A young Ngok Dinka child was killed as well as two of the attackers, though it is unclear whether the defending armed group were Ngok Dinka and/or Misseriya. 4 Ngok Dinka workers sustained wounds in the attack.

source: Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; Al Rakoba; Ayin Network; Darfur 24; UNSC
notes: On 31 July 2020, a suspected Misseriya militia group attacked Borunga village in Kass locality (South Darfur state) seemingly in retaliation after its leader had been arrested the day before and released on the morning of 31 July. At least 20,500 have been displaced between this clash and an early clash on 26 July.

Around 31 July 2020 (as reported), IDPs fleeing from Abu Dos village of Gereida locality (South Darfur state) were attacked by an unspecified group. On 28 July 2020, members of the Beja ethnic group barricaded the main road to Khartoum near Sinkat (Red Sea state) again, leading to clashes with truck drivers who were prevented from moving, leaving 5 people wounded (3 seriously). The demonstrators are calling for changes to the Eastern Track peace process, which has recently been reopened for further negotiations. [size=no report]

On 27 July 2020, a farmer was killed by unknown person(s) at or near Abu Kershola town in Abu Kershola locality (South Kordofan state). There is no further information.

At least 1,500 families have been displaced.
Around 25 July 2020 (as reported), unknown gunmen shot and wounded a woman in the area of Gurni in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 25 July 2020, around 500 residents of Misterei (West Darfur state) protested against violence in and around the town, following the death of at least 60 people in an attack the same day. [size=around 500]

Around 24 June 2020 (as reported), farmers demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state) against shortages of fuel and other agricultural inputs. [size=no report]

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
notes: On 24 June 2020, unknown attackers fired upon a UNISFA vehicle in between Goli and Todach in the disputed Abyei area (coordinates for intermediate location of Thothok used at GP2), wounding three soldiers (one seriously). The attack comes amid deteriorating security in the area.

On 24 June 2020, the military reponded to a protest in central Khartoum. The reason for the demonstration was not reported. During the demonstration, a military vehicle (presumed to be SAF) hit and wounded a child. It is unclear if the child was part of the protest. [size=no report]

On 23 June 2020, female-led demonstrations, which included IDPs, took place in El Geneina (West Darfur state) to commemorate those killed in massacres led by recently arrested former Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb. Some speakers called for greater representation for women in official positions during the transitional unity government. [size=no report]

On 23 June 2020, gunmen from Chad clashed with Sudanese pastoralists in the Wassata area (described as being in the 'far north' of West Darfur state, around 50km east of the Chadian border, and presumed to be in eastern Kulbus locality), with 16 killed in the clash (7 from Chad, 9 from Darfur, at least one of whom died later of their wounds), and 10 wounded. The source indicates fighting was sparked by an effort by the Chadian gunmen to retrieve stolen cattle and/or to avenge the death of a leader of the Chadian group killed in April.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Police
notes: On 23 June 2020, a SAF soldier who was being pursued by Military Police on suspicion of involvement in drug dealing threw a grenade at his pursuers in the market at Nertiti (Central Darfur state), wounding 8 (3 Military Police, and 5 IDPs who were in the market). The MP then shot and wounded the soldier.

On 23 June 2020, dozens of youth gathered once again in Atbara (River Nile state) in opposition to shortages of basic goods, high prices, and cuts in the supply of water. Youth burned tires on main roads in the area, and police used tear gas against the demonstrators, after attempting to negotiate with the youth the previous day. [size=dozens]

On 22 June 2020, dozens of demonstrators blocked a bridge at Soba West (Khartoum), following heavy-handed police raids in the area to stop illicit alcohol brewing, which also involved cases of theft. Police used tear gas against the demonstrators. [size=dozens]

On 22 June 2020, dozens of youth gathered in Atbara (River Nile state) in opposition to shortages of basic goods, high prices, and cuts in the supply of water. Youths burned tires on main roads in the area. [size=dozens]

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Sudan); FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Abu Tira
source: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Ayin Network
notes: On 22 June 2020, an FFC-organised protest took place at Turr in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), in opposition to violence and militia attacks in the area. Central Reserve Police (a.k.a. Abu Tira) arrested and severely beat three teachers who were attending the demonstration. [size=at least three]

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
source: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; BBC News
notes: On 21 June 2020, Ethiopian militiamen (said to be 'backed' by the Ethiopian army. Actors are here presumed to be Amhara militia and Amhara Liyu Police) attacked SAF al-Anfal (described as being on the eastern bank of the Atbara river) of El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Albanjaded]. One Sudanese soldier was killed and two wounded; SAF claimed to have repulsed Ethiopian forces and inflicted 'heavy casualties'.

actor1: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
notes: On 21 June 2020, unspecified Ethiopia forces (provisionally coded as Amhara Liyu Police) shelled an SAF camp in the Sundus area of El Fashaga locality close to the Ethiopian border, amid an escalating land dispute between the two countries. One Sudanese soldier was wounded, and parts of the camp were burnt.

On 21 June 2020, police arrested and severely beat a journalist who was taking pictures of vehicles queuing at a petrol station whilst covering fuel shortages in Suakin (Red Sea state). The incident is one of several instances of harassment directed towards journalists in Red Sea state the same week.

On 18 June 2020, supporters of the United Popular Front for Liberation and Justice staged a large march in Gedaref (Gedaref state), demanding the release of the recently arrested chairman of the rebel group, El Amin Daoud. The source indicates the demonstrators were involved in rioting. An academic was wounded either at this event or at a demonstration the previous day in Kassala. [size=large]
On 18 June 2020, pharmacists demonstrated in Khartoum against the unavailability of essential medicines. [size=no report]
On 18 June 2020, recently dismissed government employees demonstrated in Khartoum, contesting their removal following an investigation by an anti-corruption body. [size=no report]

On 17 June 2020, hundreds of supporters of the United Popular Front for Liberation and Justice marched in Kassala (Kassala state), demanding the release of the recently arrested chairman of the rebel group, El Amin Daoud. The source indicates the demonstrators were involved in rioting; security services (presumed to be police) used tear gas to disperse the group. An academic was wounded either at this event or at a demonstration the following day in Gedaref. [size=hundreds]

Around 17 June 2020 (as reported), demonstrators (including IDPs) began a sit-in at Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), in protest at continued violence in the area and in camps for displaced persons. [size=no report]

On 17 June 2020, family members of a girl who was sexually assaulted the previous day demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), denouncing the response of the security forces to the attack. Unspecified security services were deployed, although the source does not mention whether force was used against the demonstrators. [size=no report]

Around 16 June 2020 (as reported), a mass grave containing dozens of student conscripts was found at El Elafon on the outskirts of Khartoum. The students - who had deserted compulsory military training - were killed by unspecified security services linked to the Al-Ingaz regime (and presumed to have been army) at an unspecified time in 1998.

On 16 June 2020, more than 25,000 demonstrators (including IDPs) demonstrated in Mukjar town (Central Darfur state) to commemorate the March 2nd massacre carried out by Janjaweed commander Ali Kushayb. [size=more than 25,000]

On 16 June 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Ardamata IDP camp (West Darfur state), in support of the extradition of ex-Janjaweed commander Ali Kushayb to the ICC, and calling for other members of the Al Ingaz regime to be extradited. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 15 June 2020, RSF paramilitaries (initially described as Misseriya militiamen) attacked police guarding a communications tower at El Kuweik, 13km north of Kadugli town (South Kordofan state), after they were prevented from stealing fuel. One police officer was killed, and one seriously wounded.

assoc_actor_2: Ngok Clan Group (Sudan); Dinka Ethnic Group (Sudan); Pastoralists (Sudan)
notes: On 15 June 2020, suspected Misseriya gunmen raided cattle from several locations around Abyei town, including Mading Thon, Minyang, and/or Miang Anil, likely from Ngok Dinka pastoralists. Between 500 and 1,437 head of cattle were stolen. UNISFA peacekeepers attempted to pursue the raiders, but were unable to engage.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a spate of attacks (including rape) attributed to RSF paramilitaries alongside unspecified pro-government militias were reported in the Nertiti area of Central Darfur state, killing 'many' (with IDPs presumed to be a target for such attacks). Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

Around 14 June 2020, demonstrators threw stones at a member of the local authority and at a police station in the area of Umm Kamalti in Bielel locality (South Darfur state), during a demonstration following an earlier violent land dispute involving members of the Zaghawa ethnic group. [size=no report]

On 14 June 2020, fighting broke out between rival communal groups in the Umm Kamalti area of Bielel locality (South Darfur), killing one and wounding ten. At least one of the groups consisted of members of the Zaghamaw ethnic group. The clash appears to be related to a land dispute.

On 13 June 2020, armed pastoralists severely beat farmers near Shoba in Kebkabiya locality (North Darfur state), and fired weapons into the air, after the farmers refused the demands of the pastoralists to leave their farms.
On 13 June 2020, armed pastoralists fired upon IDP farmers at Aradeeba in Kass locality (South Darfur state), killing one. The attackers then looted money and animals from the survivors.

Around 13 June 2020 (as reported), an Amhara militia killed a Sudanese farmer at the Jiz al-Dud area of an unspecified locality in eastern Gedaref state [coded to Wad Faiya, El Quresha locality], and stole 400 livestock. The attack comes amid tensions in the Sudan-Ethiopia border in the area.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
notes: On 12 June 2020, SLM/A-al Nur fighters from an unspecified faction raped a woman and four of her daughters at Tairo (presumed to be close to Daya, Central Darfur state, given fighting in the area). The sexual assault may be linked to fighting the previous day between the factions.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
actor2: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)
notes: On 11 June 2020, SLM/A-Nur factions (one linked to a faction controlled by Saleh Borsa, and the other linked to a dissident commander, Mubarak Aldok) clashed at Wegi village near Daya in Rokoro locality (Central Darfur state), in fighting which is likely related to gold mining. Both sides are reported to have suffered 'heavy casualties', with 17 reported killed between this event and one on 21 May (fatalities evenly distributed across two events). 6,887 total being displaced from Wegi and nearby villages of Ila, Fara, Daya and Katiro between this clash and fighting on 21 May.

On 10 June 2020, three Arab-identified pastoralists were attacked at Kalma IDP camp (South Darfur state) by a refugee militia, after getting lost in the camp. Two of the pastoralists were killed. Note that one source suggests the victims were members of (or were mistaken for being members of) the Rapid Support Forces.
On 10 June 2020, unknown gunmen shot and wounded a farmer near Nertiti (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 10 June 2020, dozens of supporters of the outlawed NCP demonstrated in Khartoum against the newly agreed UN mission for Sudan. The supporters attacked the father of a man who had been killed in the uprising against ex-President Bashir. Police fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=dozens]

On 9 June 2020, gunmen on camels attacked a well at Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), wounding a civilian. SAF soldiers intervened, and one of the soldiers was shot dead by the gunmen. The attackers then abducted three women, releasing two later.

On 8 June 2020, the Sudan Armed Forces announced that the notorious Popular Defence Forces militia linked to the Al-Ingaz regime was to be disbanded (with earlier reports indicating it was to be renamed the Reserve Department, and placed under SAF control).

Around 7 June 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked members of the Nuba group at El Dabkaya in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), accusing them of stealing cattle belonging to the Misseriya. The source says a 'number' of people were killed and injured across this attack and others in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

Around 7 June 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked members of the Nuba group at Al Tareen in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), accusing them of stealing cattle belonging to the Misseriya. The source says a 'number' of people were killed and injured across this attack and others in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 7 June 2020, members of the Nuba ethnic group clashed with a militia from the El Hallawiyin area of El Gazira state at Mahareiba in El Kamlin locality (El Gazira state), in a long-running dispute reignited by a recent fight at a market place. 10 Nuba were injured were injured by rifle fire, and commercial buildings were destroyed.
Around 6 June 2020 (weekend of), Sudanese police were reported to have arrested 1,750 South Sudanese youth involved in a violent dispute and tortured them at a police station in Khartoum North.

On 6 June 2020, three unknown gunmen shot and killed a farmer in the area of Alsharak in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state; approximate coordinates 20km west of Abu Kershola town used). There is no further information.

Around 6 June 2020 (weekend of), South Sudanese refugees (reportedly armed with machetes) clashed with a militia of armed bricklayers in the Jaji Yusuf of area of Khartoum, in what is described as a labour dispute. 5 South Sudanese were killed and around 45 wounded. At least two of the bricklayers were wounded. The bricklayers are also reported to have torched refugee settlements in the area.

On 6 June 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked members of the Nuba group at El Fugara in Lagawa locality (West Kordofan state), accusing them of stealing cattle belonging to the Misseriya. The source says a 'number' of people were killed and injured across this attack and others in the area. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

source: Radio Dabanga; UNSC; Sudan Tribune; Darfur 24
notes: Around 5 June 2020 (as reported), government forces (comprising SAF and RSF) claimed to have re-taken territory they allegedly lost earlier that week to an unspecified faction of the SLM/A rebellion (allegedly operating in conjunction with Musa Hilal's RAC force) at Kutrum (Central Darfur state), and claimed to inflict 'heavy losses ' on the rebel groups. 36 fatalities distributed across two events (with the first event on 1 June 2020), according to a source which says 27 government soldiers were killed to 9 rebels.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 5 June 2020, RSF paramilitaries killed three displaced farmers from the Tira group of the Nuba, at a farm 2km outside of Kadugli town (South Kordofan state). Two of the farmers were tortured before being executed. The attack comes amid recent ethnicized violence in the Kadugli area.

On 4 June 2020, violence was again reported in Jebel Moon locality (West Darfur state), in the area of either Gergi Gergi in the north-west of the locality, or Jiljil and Beir Batha near Ushara to the south-east. The source indicates these were linked to land disputes involving pastoralists and recently returned refugees and IDPs (presumed to be attacks against the IDPs). 1,231 were displaced between this event and another on May 23rd; there is no information regarding fatalities or casualties.

On 4 June 2020, an unknown militia group riding in a Land Cruiser attacked Karu village in west Tawila locality (North Darfur state; location presumed to be an alternative spelling of Korru), clashing with inhabitants of the area. The attackers killed three, and one of their own was wounded. There is no further information.

On 4 June 2020, three unknown attackers shot an off-duty policeman in the Karakli area of Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), and stole his weapon. The victim died of his wounds shortly after. The three assailants have been arrested.
On 3 June 2020, unknown attackers wounded 4 and displaced 'several' at the village of El Jorof, west of Jebel Amer mine in El Sireaf locality (North Darfur state). There is no further information.
On 3 June 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched in Khartoum North, to commemorate the anniversary of the June 3rd massacre of 2019. [size=hundreds]
On 3 June 2020, a 15 year-old girl (presumed to be an IDP) was gang raped by pastoralists near Otash IDP camp in Shattai locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information.
On 3 June 2020, thousands of demonstrators marched in Khartoum, to commemorate the anniversary of the June 3rd massacre of 2019. Some demonstrators burned tires in the street. [size=thousands]

On 2 June 2020, unknown gunmen on camels and horses attacked and killed two pastoralists in the area of Martial in Tawila locality (North Darfur state), after the pastoralists prevented the gunmen from stealing camels in the area.

Around 2 June 2020, government forces have accused an unspecified faction of the SLM/A rebellion (allegedly operating in conjunction with Musa Hilal's RAC force) of attacking government forces (presumed to be military) and taking territory in the Kutrum area of Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state). The accusation has been denied by SLM/A-Al Nur rebels based in the area. There is no information on fatalities.
Around 2 June 2020, protests against water shortages and soaring food prices continued in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). [size=no report]
On 2 June 2020, PDF paramilitaries shot two farmers in Kujuria (South Kordofan state), after insinuating the farmers had stolen their cattle. One of the victims died, the other was seriously wounded.

On 2 June 2020, an unknown militia attacked the villages of Berbar and Danan (approx. 30km north of Nertiti, Central Darfur state), killing 3 women, and wounding 6 civilians (3 of whom were women). Shelling was also been reported in the area, although the connection between the militia attacks and shelling is unclear.
Around 2 June 2020, residents of El Azhari in Khartoum burned tires to denounce the continued water outages in the neighbourhood for the past two weeks. [size=no report]

Around 2 June 2020, the villages of Berbar and Danan (approx. 30km north of Nertiti, Central Darfur state) were shelled by an unknown group, killing two and wounding six. Government forces have accused an unspecified faction of the SLM/A rebellion (allegedly operating in conjunction with Musa Hilal's RAC force) of activity in the area, which has been denied by SLM/A-Al Nur rebels based in the area.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
notes: On 1 June 2020, SLM/A-Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at a checkpoint in Kutrum in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state), killing 27 soldiers, and suffering 9 fatalities of their own. Subsequent reports suggest the rebels took the area from government forces. 36 fatalities distributed across two events (with the second event on 5 June 2020).

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction) (Splinter Faction)

Over 27,000 civilians were displaced; there is no mention of casualties or fatalities.

Around 31 May 2020 (as reported), relatives of an RSF soldier who was stabbed in an unclear incident with an Abu Tira paramilitary demonstrated against his killing at El Geneina (West Darfur state). [size=no report]

Around 31 May 2020, protesters gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to denounce growing food prices and water shortages in the city. A soldier was reported to have shot multiple rounds in the air to frighten the protesters. [size=no report]

Around 30 May 2020 (as reported), members of the Ja'alin group clashed with members the Bigirma group in the Seiro El Jaaliyin area of Abu Houja locality (Sennar state), in a dispute linked to plans to convert agricultural land for residential purposes. Two people were killed, and ten injured.

Around 29 May 2020 (as reported), demonstrators gathered in Babanussa (West Kordofan state), to denounce the arrest and torture of several young men arrested earlier that day. Demonstrators torched the locality offices, vehicles, and the house of the locality director. [size=no report]

Around 29 May 2020 (as reported), SAF arrested several young men following a disagreement at a petrol station in Babanussa (West Kordofan state), amid continued petrol shortages. The men were reported to have been abused at the barracks.

actor2: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
source: Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; Sudan News Agency; Al Rakoba
notes: On 28 May 2020, Ethiopian soldiers (presumed to be Amhara Liyu Police) operating alongside Amhara militia were reported to have entered Sudanese territory at Barakat Norein (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state), following an earlier clash between SAF and the militia. One SAF captain and one child (one source says two) were killed; six SAF soldiers and at least three civilians wounded; and an unknown number were displaced. Sudanese reinforcements have deployed to the area.

On 28 May 2020, SAF clashed with Amhara militia in the area of Barakat Norein (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state), after the SAF refused to allow the Ethiopians to make use of river water in the area, amid growing tensions in the area (claimed by Ethiopia). One Ethiopian militiaman was wounded.

On 27 May 2020, an Amhara militia were reported to have raided the village of Mashra El Fursan in El Quresha locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Mashra Al Hamra']. The source does not mention whether there were fatalities or casualties.

On 27 May 2020, unknown attackers coming from the direction of Kadugli entered 'Rahad' refugee camp at an unspecified location in the Greater Kordofan region (coordinates for the refugee camp at Tegmala, South Kordofan state, used), killing one South Sudanese refugee and seriously wounding four. There is no clear motive for the attack.

source: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
notes: On 26 May 2020, militiamen attacked Bumbla village in Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), wounding at least four men with gunfire and beatings, and an unspecified number of women. An unspecified number were displaced. There is no clear motive for the attack.

source: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
notes: On 25 May 2020, armed pastoralists clashed with police at Birkat Seira (North Darfur state) after local farmers confiscated the pastoralist's cattle and took them to the police station. The pastoralists then beat 11 farmers, and destroyed their onion farms.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
source: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
notes: On 25 May 2020, unspecified militiamen in army uniform (and presumed to be RSF paramilitaries) shot an internally displaced person in the Bale area 3km north-east of Nertiti (Central Darfur state), after they accused him of stealing sheep. The victim died of his wounds shortly after.

On 24 May 2020, a militia tracked pastoralists suspecting of killing a relative of theirs to an unspecified location between Abu Jaradel (Central Darfur state) and the border with the Central African Republic. In the ensuing firefight, 10 pastoralists were killed as well as 3 of the party tracking the pastoralists.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On 23 May 2020, protesters (including Resistance Committee members) demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), denouncing high bread prices and the June 3rd massacre of 2019. Police arrested 13. [size=at least 13]

On 23 May 2020, protesters gathered in Omdurman to commemorate the upcoming anniversary of the June 3rd massacre. Police used tear gas against the demonstrators, in the vicinity of a hospital; a doctor was beaten and arrested for confronting police about the use of tear gas in the area. [size=no report]

On 23 May 2020, two armed groups clashed at the market in Dilling (South Kordofan state), in what is described as a personal dispute which escalated. Two were killed (one of whom was a civilian) and three wounded (at least of whom may be civilians). Five have been arrested, and the families ordered to leave the area.
