actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 21 May 2020, RSF paramilitaries stopped a vehicle at Albardab, north of Kadugli (South Kordofan state), and executed a civilian for being a member of the Nuba ethnic group. The attack comes amid ethnicized clashes between Nuba soldiers and Hawazma Baggara RSF.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Around 21 May 2020 (as reported), two civilians were killed and then robbed by RSF paramilitaries at an unspecified area in the Sirba locality (West Darfur state). The source suggests the two either shot or run over by the RSF. Two RSF have been arrested.
On 21 May 2020, militiamen riding camels and horses killed four civilians and wounded seven at an unspecified location in Gereida locality (South Darfur state). There is no further information.

source: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation
notes: On 21 May 2020, Fallata pastoralists attacked civilian vehicles in the Wadi Khaddari area of Gereida locality (South Darfur state; location presumed to be at the eastern edge of the locality), killing 3 and wounding 7, before looting the victims.

On 20 May 2020, a mob - initially comprising over ten family members - attacked health workers at Omdurman hospital after their relative died of knife wounds. At least five doctors were wounded after stones were thrown at them, before a larger mob (who were not connected to the family) of at least 30 people formed and attacked security guards of the hospital. Doctors at the hospital subsequently went on strike in response to the attack. [size=more than 30]

Around 20 May 2020 (as reported), large numbers of demonstrators gathered in Khartoum (and in unspecified cities elsewhere in Sudan) to protest against the coronavirus lockdown measures, and what they described as 'neocolonial' interventions by the UN and World Bank. [size=large]
On 19 May 2020, unknown armed men killed a merchant and wounded another civilian between Nertiti and Gerni (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 19 May 2020, the SLM/A faction under Minni Minawi announced it would withdraw from the SRF rebel alliance, which is currently negotiating in peace talks with the government in Juba. The following day the SRF stated that they accepted his withdrawal, and resignation as Vice-President of the SRF.

On 16 May 2020, armed men (including some wearing military uniforms) attacked the villages of Tirti and Khairwajid in Beida locality (West Darfur state), in what appears to be a reprisal attack following the killing of a local relative of the men. 2 were killed (fatalities split across two events), between 17 and 28 abducted, and both villages were torched. One source indicates that the conflict is organised around ethnic lines, involving Arab and Masalit groups (with the Masalit presumed to be the victims of the attack). 1,401 people were displaced.

On 16 May 2020, armed men (including some wearing military uniforms) attacked the villages of Tirti and Khairwajid in Beida locality (West Darfur state), in what appears to be a reprisal attack following the killing of a local relative of the men. 2 were killed (fatalities split across two events), between 17 and 28 abducted, and both villages were torched. One source indicates that the conflict is organised around ethnic lines, involving Arab and Masalit groups (with the Masalit presumed to be the victims of the attack). 1,401 people were displaced.

On 15 May 2020, unspecified 'militiamen', who had killed three the previous day, launched an attack in the area of Katura in Tawila locality (North Darfur state). The attackers fired upon a well, before stealing livestock. It does not appear as though anyone was injured in the attack.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 15 May 2020, suspected RSF paramilitaries killed two civilians and wounded another in two districts of Kadugli (South Kordofan state). The attacks follow violent unrest in and around the town, related to ethnicized clashes between Nuba soldiers and Hawazma Baggara RSF.

On 14 May 2020, internal clashes between unspecified security units (presumed to be army) broke out in Rokoro town (Central Darfur state), spilling into the hospital. An NGO staff member was seriously wounded in the crossfire. There is no further information, including whether there were fatalities.
On 14 May 2020, unspecified 'militiamen' killed three civilians in the area of Katur in Tawila locality (North Darfur state), before stealing livestock.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
source: UNOCHA; AP; Crisis Watch; Radio Dabanga
notes: Around 12 May 2020 (between 11 - 12 May), intense fighting was reported in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), in clashes which have been linked to ethnic tensions between Nuba SAF personnel and Hawazma Baggara RSF. 17 people were killed on 12 May (and another 9 in clashes between RSF and SAF on 13 May) with a total of 26 fatalities and at least 19 injured. Houses have been torched and looted, including in Tillo IDP camp adjacent to the city. At least 18,000 IDPs were displaced again due to the fighting.

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
notes: On 12 May 2020, an unspecified group attacked members of UNISFA Force Protection assigned to protect members of the Joint Border Verification and Monitoring Mechanism, as they travelled from Kadugli to Murta (South Kordofan state). The UNISFA vehicle was damaged, but no injuries occurred.
On 11 May 2020, health workers demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for protective equipment to be supplied in the midst of rising numbers of coronavirus cases. [size=no report]

Around 11 May 2020, unknown attackers abducted two Ingessana pastoralists in the Amura jungle area of Geissan locality (Blue Nile state), in what was likely an ethnically-motivated attack (pastoralists belonging to other ethnic groups were not seized). The bodies of the two victims were found two days later in the village of Khartoum Belail.

Around 11 May 2020 (as reported), a man was killed and several were injured in a clash between followers of a Sheikh and members of the public in the area of Babiker well, east of Khartoum. The source says the conflict was linked to access to the well, and was not religious in nature. [size=no report]

On 11 May 2020, residents of Nertiti (Central Darfur state) demonstrated against a surge in violent attacks (including rape and looting) in the area, calling for greater protection from authorities and for militias to be disarmed. [size=no report]
On 11 May 2020, 'militiamen' shot dead a civilian near the UNAMID compound west of Nertiti (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 10 May 2020, during a three day clash between Beni Amir and Nuba irregular militia, 11 people were killed (8 Beni Amir, 2 Nuba, 1 unknown) in the city of Kassala (Kassala state) and around 100 were wounded (70 Beni Amir, 30 Nuba). Hundreds of civilians have been displaced, and a number of houses torched. It is currently unclear what sparked the fighting which was at its most intense on 8 and 9 May; 59 have been arrested. Fatalities distributed across three events.

On 10 May 2020, unknown gunmen abducted three farmers (including an IDP) from Bari valley near Murnei (West Darfur state). The source suggests that the attack was related to recent arrests of cattle thieves by authorities in the area.

On 9 May 2020, during a three day clash between Beni Amir and Nuba irregular militia, 11 people were killed (8 Beni Amir, 2 Nuba, 1 unknown) in the city of Kassala (Kassala state) and around 100 were wounded (70 Beni Amir, 30 Nuba). Hundreds of civilians have been displaced, and a number of houses torched. It is currently unclear what sparked the fighting which was at its most intense on 8 and 9 May; 59 have been arrested. Fatalities distributed across three events.
On 8 May 2020, unknown attackers killed a man and wounded two others (including the son of the deceased) in the Abu Kershola area (South Kordofan state), and robbed 600 head of cattle.

Around 8 May 2020, police fired tear gas at rioting prisoners at the central prison in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), after the prisoners had earliers seized part of the prison, calling for their release from prison in line with official guidelines for the release of some prisoners as a coronavirus precaution measure. Several injuries were reported, and the source indicates that prisoners threw tear gas canisters back at the police. [size=at least several]
On 8 May 2020, around 60 PDF paramilitaries attacked a cattle camp at Sefaifeer near Abu Kershola (South Kordofan state), killing one pastoralist and stealing over 300 head of cattle.

On 8 May 2020, during a three day clash between Beni Amir and Nuba irregular militia, 11 people were killed (8 Beni Amir, 2 Nuba, 1 unknown) in the city of Kassala (Kassala state) (with deaths occurring on 8 and 9 May) and around 100 were wounded (70 Beni Amir, 30 Nuba). Hundreds of civilians have been displaced, and a number of houses torched. It is currently unclear what sparked the fighting which was at its most intense on 8 and 9 May; 59 have been arrested. Fatalities distributed across three events.
Around 8 May 2020 (as reported), armed pastoralists abducted a child and stole 45 sheep near Golo (Central Darfur state), before killing a member of a vigilante group who pursued them.

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) Prison Guards
notes: On 7 May 2020, prisoners rioted at Shalla prison close to El Fasher (North Darfur state), after 96 inmates were released as a coronavirus precaution measure, and an unspecified number remained incarcerated. Prison guards killed one prisoner and wounded 11 others. [size=at least 12]

On 7 May 2020, armed pastoralists attacked two farmers with hand weapons, after the farmers attempted to clear them from their farms in the area of Goz Beina (North Darfur state), killing one and seriously wounding the other.
On 7 May 2020, protesters gathered in Sinkat (Red Sea state), protesting against continued problems with the supply of water and electricity in the town. [size=no report]

Around 6 May 2020, prisoners rioted at the central prison in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for their release from prison in line with official guidelines for the release of some prisoners as a coronavirus precaution measure. [size=no report]

On 5 May 2020, armed men on horseback (and presumed to be Misseriya, given recent violence in the area) attacked South Sudanese refugees at El Meiram (West Kordofan state), wounding 18 and torching 200 dwellings. 400 were displaced. The attack may be linked to recent violence between Ngok Dinka and Misseriya in and around Abyei.

source: Darfur 24; Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Al Taghyeer (Sudan); Radio Dabanga
notes: On 5 May 2020, Fellata and Rizeigat communal militias clashed in various locations in adjoining localities in South Darfur state, killing at least 31, and wounding dozens. Fighting broke out in the areas of Balail, Hajir Togo, Umm Kuja, Abu Jabra, Donkey Dereisa, Khor Shamam and other unspecified locations in the localities of Dimsu, Tullus, and Katayla (all in South Darfur state). A large number of cattle were stolen, which have may provoked the fight. At least 20,000 head of cattle have been recovered, and security forces deployed in the area. Fatalities distributed across six events.

source: Darfur 24; Al Taghyeer (Sudan); Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga

A large number of cattle were stolen, which have may provoked the fight. At least 20,000 head of cattle have been recovered, and security forces deployed in the area. Fatalities distributed across six events.

Fighting broke out in the areas of Balail, Hajir Togo (approximate coordinates from Toga, El Salam locality, used), Umm Kuja, Abu Jabra, Donkey Dereisa, Khor Shamam and other unspecified locations in the localities of Dimsu, Tullus, and Katayla (all in South Darfur state). A large number of cattle were stolen, which have may provoked the fight. At least 20,000 head of cattle have been recovered, and security forces deployed in the area. Fighting broke out in the areas of Balail, Hajir Togo, Umm Kuja, Abu Jabra, Donkey Dereisa, Khor Shamam and other unspecified locations in the localities of Dimsu, Tullus, and Katayla (all in South Darfur state). A large number of cattle were stolen, which have may provoked the fight. At least 20,000 head of cattle have been recovered, and security forces deployed in the area. Fatalities distributed across six events.

On 3 May 2020, around a hundred supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party demonstrated in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), against a proposed extension of the United Nation's presence in the country. [size=about a hundred]

On 3 May 2020, dozens of supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party demonstrated in Kosti (White Nile state), against a proposed extension of the United Nation's presence in the country. [size=dozens]
On 3 May 2020, unknown attackers wounded four Ngok Dinka civilians as they travelled from Anet to Abyei town in the disputed Abyei area. There is no further information.

On 3 May 2020, demonstrators gathered in Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for the removal of the military governor and for members of Muslim alms committees to be replaced. SAF soldiers dispersed the crowds with tear gas, and severely beat a demonstrator who was recording the event on his phone. [size=no report]

On 3 May 2020, supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party demonstrated in El Gazira state (presumed to be at the state capital of Wad Medani), against a proposed extension of the United Nation's presence in the country. [size=no report]

On 3 May 2020, dozens of supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party demonstrated in Khartoum, against a proposed extension of the United Nation's presence in the country. The demonstrators burned tires and blocked roads in the capital. [size=dozens]

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: Around 1 May 2020 (as reported), Resistance Committee members demonstrated against a rise in petrol prices in the Soba area of Khartoum. Police reportedly assaulted the demonstrators, and fired tear gas at them. [size=no report]

On 1 May 2020, an SAF soldier fired upon a family in the area of Helat Elfaki in Dilling locality (South Kordofan state), killing the father and a son, and wounding three other family members. There is no clear motive for the attack; the soldier has reportedly been apprehended.

On 30 April 2020, about a hundred supporters of deposed President Omar el Bashir and the outlawed National Congress Party demonstrated at Kober Prison (Khartoum North), calling for NCP officials to be released from prison. Police arrested 23 demonstrators. [size=about a hundred]

On 30 April 2020, Ngok Dinka and Misseriya clashed in the Sumayah/War Abar area in the vicinity of El Meiram (West Kordofan state). Two Misseriya and three Ngok Dinka were killed, and an unspecified number of civilians displaced.

On 30 April 2020, unknown gunmen attacked three female IDPs collecting firewood near Um Dereisaya west of Shangil Tobay (North Darfur state). The gunmen seized a 12 year-old female IDP, and repeatedly raped her.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On 29 April 2020, at least 12 Resistance Committee members demonstrated in Gereida (South Darfur state), denouncing the Zakat (alms) committee's decision to keep part of the food they were due to distribute to dusplaced persons during Ramadan. Police arrested 12. [size=at least 12]

Around 29 April 2020 (week of), unspecified militiamen on horseback abducted a 16 year-old female IDP who was looking after her goats 2km north of Nertiti (Central Darfur state), and stole her goats. There is no further information.

Around 28 April 2020 (as reported), dozens of residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) burned tires on the main road of the city, to denounce continuing problems with the supply of water and electricity. Police dispersed the crowds with tear gas. [size=dozens]
On 27 April 2020, health workers gathered at the hospital in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the government to honour their sugar ration. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 27 April 2020, RSF paramilitaries arrested an activist in Ed Damazin in Blue Nile state (after previously arresting him earlier in the month), and tortured him whilst in custody. He was released the following day.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Around 27 April 2020 (as reported), an RSF paramilitary killed a police officer and two civilians at a well in Ed Daein (East Darfur state). A child was also wounded. The RSF soldier had reportedly been beaten by the police officer when he went to the well the previous day.

On 26 April 2020, 18 Misseriya pastoralists were killed and an unspecified number wounded by alleged South Sudanese gunmen in the area of El Gurenti near Meriam (West Kordofan state), according to the National Uma Party (note that the event has not been corroborated in other sources).

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Border Guards
notes: On 25 April 2020, Border Guard paramilitaries attacked a female farmer who had chased livestock away from her farm near Abata (Central Darfur state), breaking both her hands.

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
notes: On 24 April 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked UNISFA peacekeepers at Alal in the disputed Abyei area. UNISFA killed two Misseriya between this and another attack the same day at Nainai (fatalities distributed evenly across two events).

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
notes: On 24 April 2020, Misseriya militiamen attacked UNISFA peacekeepers in the vicinity of Nainai in the disputed Abyei area. UNISFA killed two Misseriya between this and another attack the same day at Alal (fatalities distributed evenly across two events).

On 24 April 2020, demonstrators surrounded the prosecutor's office in Dilling (South Kordofan state), preventing the prosecutor or his employees from leaving. The demonstration was connected to an earlier kidnapping of two children (which was linked to a dispute surrounding stolen cattle). After the two children were released, the crowd vacated the area. [size=no report]

On 23 April 2020, scores of demonstrators gathered once again in Haji Yusuf in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to denounce the slow pace of the revolution and continued economic problems and shortages of essential goods. The demonstrators burned tires on the roads. [size=scores]
On 23 April 2020, demonstrators gathered in Soba East in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to protest against continuing shortages of bread and fuel. [size=no report]

On 23 April 2020, two unspecified groups clashed near Singita (South Darfur state) in what is described as a 'tribal fight', which escalated from an unspecified 'simple social problem'. At least 11 were killed and 18 injured. Authorities intervened to separate the groups, and arrested 200 suspects.

Around 23 April 2020, an Ethiopian Amhara farmer militia attacked SAF soldiers in the Khor Zaraf area in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Basalam], east of Doka garrison. One SAF soldier was killed and three wounded. The attack is reportedly linked to disputes between constituencies in Ethiopia and Sudan over control of the Fashaga triangle.

From 18 to 22 April 2020, scores of protesters gathered in Haji Yusuf in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to denounce the slow pace of the revolution and continued economic problems and shortages of essential goods. [size=scores]

On 22 April 2020, police assaulted a senior doctor on the White Nile bridge between Omdurman and Khartoum and stole his phone, ostensibly as part of coronavirus lockdown measures. The attack prompted a strike by doctors at his hospital in Omdurman.

On 22 or 23 April 2020, relatives of a man killed in an interpersonal dispute attacked the village of Keng Ban Jadeed (where the killer hails from) in Saraf Omra locality (North Darfur state), burning dwellings and foodstores, and stealing a small number of livestock. 10 families were displaced to nearby villages, and an unspecified number of people displaced throughout the valley.

From 18 to 22 April 2020, scores of protesters gathered in Haji Yusuf in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to denounce the slow pace of the revolution and continued economic problems and shortages of essential goods. [size=scores]

On 21 April 2020, armed pastoralists attacked the village of Tamur Jamil/Tamr Bol Jamal, 18km north-east of Zalingei (Central Darfur state), killing at least 2 with firearms, and seriously wounding 5 (some of whom were beaten). 7 women were reported to have been raped. Hundreds were displaced in the attack, with 70 houses, shops and the market torched. The attack follows a dispute which arose when the body of a young pastoralist was found in a well.

On 21 April 2020, a reported 50,000 miners demonstrated in Delgo (Northern state), following the closure of mining markets in Delgo and Halfa locality under coronavirus protection measures. The demonstrators torched the police station, the Sudanese Mining Company building, and a Muslim alms chamber. Police used tear gas and live rounds against the demonstrators, wounding an unspecified number, and two police were wounded. [size=50,000]

From 18 to 22 April 2020, scores of protesters gathered in Haji Yusuf in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to denounce the slow pace of the revolution and continued economic problems and shortages of essential goods. [size=scores]

On 20 April 2020, demonstrators gathered in several locales in Khartoum, to protest against the ongoing economic crisis and shortages of essential goods, including fuel and foodstuffs. In one such demonstration, vehicle owners blocked Nile Street in Khartoum after a petrol station they had been queuing a closed. [size=no report]

From 18 to 22 April 2020, scores of protesters gathered in Haji Yusuf in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to denounce the slow pace of the revolution and continued economic problems and shortages of essential goods. [size=scores]
On or around 19 April 2020, sanitation workers and street cleaners protested in the Jabra area of Khartoum, calling for a range of improvements in their pay and conditions. [size=no report]

From 18 to 22 April 2020, scores of protesters gathered in Haji Yusuf in Eastern Nile locality (Khartoum state), to denounce the slow pace of the revolution and continued economic problems and shortages of essential goods. [size=scores]

On 17 April 2020, an unknown armed group fired two RPG rockets at the market in Abyei town. The rockets did not hit the market, and did not cause casualties. The attackers then stole an unspecified number of livestock from the area.

On 17 April 2020, dozens of supporters of the deposed President Omar el Bashir and the outlawed National Congress Party marched in Kassala (Kassala state), chanting slogans in opposition to the civilian Prime Minister. [size=dozens]

On 16 April 2020, unknown gunmen fired at a civilians leaving a sports club at or near Shangil Tobay in Dar El Salam locality (North Darfur state), killing one and wounding two. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 16 April 2020, supporters of the uprising in Sudan marched in Atbara (River Nile state), in a counter-protest to recent marches conducted by supporters of the deposed NCP regime of Omar el Bashir. [size=no report]

On 16 April 2020, hundreds of supporters of the deposed President Omar el Bashir and the outlawed National Congress Party marched in Khartoum (and attempted to gain entrance into the military HQ), calling for the military leadership of the Sovereign Council to seize power from the civilian elements of the power-sharing government. Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas. [size=hundreds]

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the leader of an unspecified Chadian group was killed at an unspecified location in Beida locality (West Darfur state), with the attackers implied to be a Sudanese pastoralist militia. There is no further information - including as to whether a firefight took place - and it is unclear whether others were killed in the event.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a relative of detained RAC leader Musa Hilal was beaten by RSF paramilitaries after being transferred to the RSF detention facility in Al Manshiya (Khartoum), after having been detained for over a month at the RSF detention facility in Al Riyadh [coded to Khartoum - Manshiya].

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), police severely beat a doctor at the hospital in Jebel Aulia (Khartoum state), after doctors requested that the hospital be evacuated due to a suspected outbreak of coronavirus. Doctors subsequently went on strike.

source: Radio Dabanga; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Tamazuj
notes: On 13 April 2020, suspected Misseriya pastoralists operating alongside men in military uniforms (which one source describes as being members of the Sudan Armed Forces) attacked a Ngok Dinka village of Mabok in south-eastern Abyei, killing at least 4, and abducted 2 children. Another adult is missing. The attackers torched around 60 dwellings, and stole property and around 100 goats. The attack follows recent failed peace talks between the Misseriya and Ngok Dinka.

On 12 and 13 April 2020, two unspecified ethnic militias, who were involved in raiding and vigilante activity which led to two deaths on 10 April 2020, carried out separate abuctions on members of each other's communities, with two of the vigilantes abducted and taken to Abu Kershola, and three of the group involved in cattle raids abducted and taken to Umm Barambita (both in Abu Kershola locality, South Kordofan state). The source does not mention that any exchange of fire took place. Military forces have intervened in the area.

On 13 April 2020, an unknown armed group attacked two vehicles in the area of Maliha in Bara locality (North Kordofan state), one of which appears to have been a police vehicle (or a car transporting a police officer). A police officer and the driver of that vehicle were killed, and two passengers in the other car were wounded.

On or around 12 April 2020, prisoners in the main prison in Nyala (South Darfur state) attacked a judge who was inspecting the prison, and stole valuables. The attack comes amid a hunger strike in the overcrowded prison, in which prisoners are calling for their release. [size=no report]

On 12 and 13 April 2020, two unspecified ethnic militias, who were involved in raiding and vigilante activity which led to two deaths on 10 April 2020, carried out separate abuctions on members of each other's communities, with two of the vigilantes abducted and taken to Abu Kershola, and three of the group involved in cattle raids abducted and taken to Umm Barambita (both in Rashad locality, South Kordofan state). The source does not mention that any exchange of fire took place. Military forces have intervened in the area.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On or before 12 April 2020, unspecified government militiamen (presumed to be RSF paramilitaries) beat four female IDPs who were gathering firewood near Bur Seleiba in Sirba locality (West Darfur state). Two were seriously wounded.

On 12 April 2020, dozens of female supporters of the outlawed NCP regime marched in Khartoum (and operating under the guise of the 'Unified Popular Movement') in spite of the current lockdown. The protesters were calling for the removal of the FFC government, and an end to what they described as neoliberal and neoclonial interventions into Sudanese politics. Police arrested 30 demonstrators, including the leader of the protest. [size=dozens]

On 10 April 2020, a vigilante militia clashed with an armed group who had been stealing cattle that same day in the areas of Kortala (Habila locality) and Abu Kershola (Rashad locality), both in South Kordofan state. The clash, which the source indicates is at least partly ethnic, resulted in two of the vigilante group being killed and five wounded, and two bandits wounded. The location of the clash is not specified.
On 9 April 2020, 3 Misseriya pastoralists were killed near Marial Achak in the disputed Abyei area by unknown attackers. There is no further information.

On 9 April 2020, demonstrators (assumed IDPs) blocked the main road at Turr (Central Darfur state) with stones and burning tires, to contest continued attacks on IDPs by armed groups in the area. The demonstrators threw stones at an army commander as he attempted to speak with them, at which point soldiers opened fire upon the demonstrators, wounding one. [size=no report]

On 9 April 2020, nurses protested in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), before going on strike over a lack of medical equipment at the El Obeid Teaching Hospital, and the failure of the director of the hospital to address the issue. [size=no report]

On 9 April 2020, unknown gunmen abducted two IDPs east of Turr in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state). A combined team of soldiers and local vigilantes arrested the perpetrators and freed the abductees.

On 9 April 2020, hundreds of supporters of the outlawed NCP and the deposed President Omar al Bashir demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the removal of Prime Minister Hamdock's transitional government, an improvement in living standards, and for unspecified regional powers to be kept out of Sudanese political affairs. Sources suggest the protests were organised by a group known as 'Hashed' and/or 'The Unified Popular Movement', who appear to be Islamist supporters of the NCP regime. [size=hundreds]

On 8 April 2020, unknown gunmen attempted to assassinate a lawyer involved in anti-corruption activities (directed against the deposed al-Ingaz regime) and the secretary of the West Kordofan branch of the Baath Party at Muglad (West Kordofan state). Although their vehicle was damaged, neither of the men were injured. The Baath party alleged that the attackers were members of the General Intelligence Service (formerly NISS), although this is unconfirmed at this time.

On 7 April 2020, violence continued in Lagawa (West Kordofan state) following an incident a petrol station the previous day. An unknown group killed a soldier and several dwellings were torched in the town. Additional security forces have been deployed, although there is no further information on the precise events at this time.
On 7 April 2020, dozens of demonstrators burned tires on the highway running through Sinkat (Red Sea state), after a driver killed a 10 year-old boy in a hit and run incident. [size=dozens]

On 6 April 2020, gunmen wearing military fatigues (and recorded as such) fired upon a commercial vehicle near Guldo (Central Darfur state), after the vehicle did not stop for the armed men. A student was killed in the gunfire.

On 6 April 2020, armed pastoralists attacked and killed two SAF soldiers at Boli near Sortony IDP camp in Kebkabiya locality (North Darfur state). A female IDP was wounded in the attack. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 6 April 2020, unknown armed men intercepted a group of 47 IDPs from Nertiti camp who were farming in their home areas near Kori, 3km north-west of Nertiti (Central Darfur state). The men beat the IDPs with rifle butts, sticks and whips, wounding 9. One (or several) vehicles used by the IDPs were burnt.

On 6 April 2020, police intervened in a fight at a petrol station in Lagawa (West Kordofan state) amid a national fuel crisis, leading to one of the police officers to be stabbed and wounded. Police then opened fire on the crowd, killing one, and seriously wounding three. [size=at least five]

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On 6 April 2020, protesters, including Resistance Committee members, marched in Kassala (Kassala state) to commemorate the anniversary of the 6 April 2019 march to the army HQ in Khartoum - a key date in the uprising. [size=no report]

On and/or after 6 April 2020, striking doctors demonstrated at the hospital in Ed Daein (East Darfur state), after an RSF lieutenant assaulted a doctor at the hospital and police refused to process the case. [size=no report]

On 6 April 2020, 'a great number' of protesters marched in Khartoum to commemorate the anniversary of the 6 April 2019 march to the army HQ in Khartoum - a key date in the uprising. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=a great number]

On 6 April 2020, unknown gunmen abducted 8 IDPs (from Hamidiya camp) who were gathering firewood approximately 20km east of the camp along the Zalingei-Nyala road in Central Darfur state. There is no further information.

On 5 April 2020, farmers protested in the Diem Al-Mashayikha area in an unknown locality of southern El Gazira state, following a series of fires which have destroyed crops in the area. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
assoc_actor_2: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On 2 April 2020, a prominent Resistance Committee member intervened to prevent Military Intelligence personnel from stealing petrol from a petrol station in Sennar town (Sennar state), amid a severe fuel crisis. The soldiers then beat the activist.

On 31 March 2020, ten PDF paramilitaries abducted three farmers and a driver near Kokaya in Habila locality (South Kordofan state), and took them to the forest of Elmughafal, where the victims were robbed. The following day, local vigilantes tracked down the abductees, causing the PDF militiamen to flee.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On 31 March 2020, FFC protesters began a sit-in at Songo/Sengo in El Radoom locality (South Darfur state), calling for the dismissal of the locality director, an end to corruption in the locality, and a percentage of mining proceeds (from an operation which involves the deputy head of the Sovereign Council) to be put to improving conditions in the area. As of 12 April 2020, it was reported that the ongoing sit-in had so far lasted 12 days, and resulted in the removal of the director. [size=no report]
On 30 March 2020, dozens of residents of El Obeid (North Kordofan state) demonstrated against recent water outages in the town. [size=dozens]

assoc_actor_2: WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (Russia)
notes: On or before 30 March 2020, gunmen (presumed to be Arab-identified pastoralists, who are based in the area) 'seized' five Russian crew members of a WFP-marked helicopter at or near Jebel Silk (described as being west of Murnei and close to an area called Arum in the north-west of Habila locality, West Darfur state), amid violent tension in the area. The crew claimed they were forced into an emergency landing, and have been handed to authorities in Habila town, who are investigating the incident.
On 29 March 2020, residents of Kebkabiya (North Darfur state) demonstrated against problems at the local hospital, including a lack of medical specialists. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On or around 29 March 2020, members of the Gereida Resistance Committee protested in Gereida (South Darfur state), calling for the suspension of the Land Authority in the area amid claims of corruption. The Land Authority was temporarily shut down by the demonstration. [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) Prison Guards
notes: On 29 March 2020, prisoners at El Hoda prison in Omdurman rioted, calling for their release in order to reduce their risk of catching coronavirus. Prison guards suppressed the riot and fired tear gas, with one prisoner reported to have suffered a minor wound on his hand. [size=no report]

On 29 March 2020, Arab-identified pastoralists attacked gunmen (suspected of being from the Masalit tribe) in the area of Jebel Silk in West Darfur (described as being west of Murnei and close to an area called Arum in the north-west of Habila locality, West Darfur state), in retaliation for an attack the previous day. Eight people were reported to have been killed, and one wounded.

On 28 March 2020, gunmen travelling in four-wheel drive vehicles (and suspected of belonging to the Masalit ethnic group) attacked Arab-identified pastoralists at Jebel Silk in West Darfur (described as being west of Murnei and close to an area called Arum in the north-west of Habila locality, West Darfur state). Two pastoralists were wounded.

On 27 March 2020 (and potentially on 26 March), residents of northern El Gazira torched dwellings belonging to the Kanabi group (originally seasonal workers from western Sudan brought to the El Gazira scheme, many of whom have lived in the area for generations). The attackers had claimed the Kanabi had been 'trespassing'. 64 have been arrested in connection with the attack. [size=at least 64]

On 26 March 2020, a militia from the area of Taya in Basundah locality (Gedaref state) clashed with Amhara militiamen who had recently abducted several residents of the village. Three of the Ethiopian militiamen were killed, and two captured. Event presumed to have occurred in the area of Taya.
On 26 March 2020, residents of El Obeid (North Kordofan state) demonstrated against recent water outages in the town. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On or before 25 March 2020, Sudanese doctors were assaulted by Somali military in the area of the Rapid Support Forces barracks in Khartoum state. The assaults allegedly occurred after the military refused to observe the screening measures set-up to control the spread of coronavirus.

On or before 24 March 2020, gunmen fired upon a crowd at Gaderni/Qadrni in West Darfur state (described as being 70km east of El Geniena, in Kreinik locality), after residents of the area objected to the gunmen 'molesting' girls at a water pump. A 12 year-old girl was killed, and an adult wounded. The attackers have been arrested.
On 24 March 2020, a judge was assaulted by soldiers at a fuel station in El Faw (El Faw, Gedaref). Judges began an open-ended strike following the attack.

source: Middle East Eye; Radio Dabanga; Radio Miraya
notes: On 23 March 2020, the Sudanese government declared a state of emergency in response to multiple cases of the coronavirus being confirmed in the county, closing schools, borders and airports, and many workplaces. A night-time curfew was introduced, and public gatherings prohibited. On 26 March 2020, the measures were further tightened to suspend public transport. On 18 April 2020, a three-week lockdown of Khartoum and Omdurman was announced, with the military governor of Khartoum state being fired by PM Hamdock after the governor refused to uphold the restrictions on religious gatherings. On 1 May 2020, the lockdown was implemented by military governors in several states in eastern and western Sudan, including North and South Darfur states, Red Sea state, and Gedaref state.
On 21 March 2020, a woman was killed when pastoralist herders launched an attack against displaced returnees in Esheraya village (Abu Jabra, East Darfur). The village was torched during the attack.

On or around 19 March 2020, hundreds of demonstrators blocked the entrance to the bus terminal in El Fasher (North Darfur state), protesting against rapidly increasing prices of bus tickets. [size=hundreds]

On 19 March 2020, government soldiers from South Sudan allegedly attacked Misseriya pastoralists in the area of Kalak east of Abyei in West Kordofan state along the disputed border between Sudan and South Sudan, killing nine, and wounding at least one. There is no further information.

On 18 March 2020, dozens of demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), condemning the lack of basic services in the town (including shortages of bread, fuel and power). The demonstrators burned tires on the roads in the centre of the town. [size=dozens]

On or before 18 March 2020, demonstrators, including journalists, gathered outside of the Blue Nile TV Channel HQ in Khartoum, calling for the replacement of the channel's director, and the reinstatement of two recently dismissed employees. [size=no report]

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)

On 17 March 2020, demonstrators burned tires in Khartoum North, calling for the Committee of Inquiry to release its final report on the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]
On 17 March 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched in Khartoum, calling for the Committee of Inquiry to release its final report on the June 3rd massacre. [size=hundreds]

On 15 March 2020, unknown attackers shot and killed the head of South Kordofan branch of the Islamic Da'awa Organization in Kadugli town (South Kordofan state). There is no further information.

On 15 March 2020, residents of Nertiti (Central Darfur state) demonstrated against fuel shortages and high fuel prices, blocking the road between Nertiti and Nyala. [size=no report]

On 12 March 2020, armed pastoralists fired upon civilians watering livestock near Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), wounding one woman with gunfire, and another when they beat her with a rifle butt. The attackers then stole around 85 sheep and goats.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change

On 9 March 2020, an unknown group (described as 'militants') torched a church in Bout in Al Tadamon locality (Blue Nile state).

On 9 March 2020, armed pastoralists attacked the villages of Dewana and Um Gunja near Hijer in Bielel locality (South Darfur state), following a fight between a farmer and pastoralist the previous day, in which the pastoralist was killed. At least 12 were killed in Dewana and at least 1 was killed in Um Gunja; a smaller number of injuries have been reported.

source: Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga; Al Jazeera
notes: On 9 March 2020, unknown attackers planted an explosive device near Kober bridge (Khartoum North) which detonated as the Prime Ministers' motorcade approached. The PM was unhurt, and one security officer (recorded as police) was wounded on the shoulder. Several suspects have been arrested. Initial reports suggested that weapons were fired upon the motorcade, although this is not confirmed.
On 9 March 2020, supporters of the Prime Minister demonstrated in Gedaref (Gedaref state), following an attempt on the PM's life earlier that day. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, demonstrators gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state) to protest against water shortages and power cuts. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas, igniting six dwellings the process. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, seven armed men (five on horseback) described as 'militiamen' shot and gang raped a 17 year-old female IDP in the Kalamakeri area to the east of Turr in Nertiti locality (Central Darfur state). She is being treated in hospital.
On 9 March 2020, an unexploded ordnance detonated at a house in Jalahanti in Agig locality (Red Sea state), killing two children (one of whom died later), and injuring several others.

On 5 March 2020, demonstrators burned tires at an intersection in Khartoum, against a lack of transport options in the city. [size=no report]

On 4 March 2020, armed pastoralists attacked the village of Turr in an unspecified locality of Central Darfur state (note there are several villages with this name in the state), wounding two IDP school students, and stealing five donkeys. The governor of Central Darfur state has disputed that this event occurred.
On 4 March 2020, armed pastoralists fired upon IDPs who were making bricks, at an unspecified location in Central Darfur state. Four were wounded, two seriously. There is no further information.

On 3 March 2020, unknown gunmen attacked pastoralists in the Kouri area, north of Nertiti town (Central Darfur state), prompting a firefight that left four or five dead across both sides, and several wounded. Whilst one source describes this as a clash between 'armed bandits' and pastoralists, a more detailed and recent source implies that this was an organised attack on the pastoralists by an unknown group.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On 3 March 2020, FFC and resistance committee protesters demonstrated in Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state), calling for a health director who had spoken out against corruption to remain in Ab Jubaiha rather than being transferred to Dilling. [size=no report]
On 3 March 2020, local residents blocked roads and burned tires in Karima town (Northern state), following surging bread prices due to a lack of subsidised flour. [size=no report]

As reported on 3 March 2020, an SAF military commander is alleged to have seized 36km of land from IDPs around the Hashaba area of Kutum locality (North Darfur state), in order to pursue gold mining activities. The area has become militarised as a result.

On 3 March 2020, residents of Manaser in Berber locality (River Nile state) protested on the nearby road to Ed Damer, preventing vehicles from passing. The protesters called for the restoration of electricity to the area. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces

On 2 March 2020, locals demonstrated during a visit by PM Hamdock to Kassala, calling for the removal of the military governor, and decrying the lack of development projects underway in the area. [size=no report]

On 1 March 2020, armed pastoralists attacked 13 displaced women and children collecting straw near Kutum (North Darfur state). The attackers shot seven, and others were beaten with batons and whips. Three are seriously injured.

On 1 March 2020, farmers began a sit-in protest at the Ministry of Agriculture building in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), calling for greater support from the government, including subsidies. [size=no report]

On 29 February 2020, an unknown group torched a church in Block 18 of Jabarona IDP camp west of Omdurman (Khartoum state). On or after 28 February 2020, relatives of a man shot dead near Murnei protested in Murnei town (West Darfur state), calling for the perpetrators to be arrested. [size=no report]

On 28 February 2020, an unknown armed group attacked the police station at Sullu in Azum locality (Central Darfur state), torching the station, and stealing a large number of firearms and two vehicles. Seven people have been arrested. The source does not specify whether a firefight occurred, and does not mention any fatalities.
On 27 February 2020, suspected Misseriya gunmen shot and wounded two Ngok Dinka men travelling between Abyei town and Amiet market in the disputed Abyei area. The motive for the attack is unclear.

On 27 February 2020, SAF soldiers raided a gold mine close to Salmeen in Qala El Nahal locality (Gedaref state), after miners refused to vacate the mine. Soldiers used tear gas and rubber bullets against the miners, wounding 5 (2 seriously).

On 25 February 2020, employees of the Water Authority in Khartoum state demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for the removal of the current director and an end to corruption in the Authority. [size=no report]

On 25 February 2020, dozens of protesters from Blue Nile state protested in Khartoum, expressing concerns about the effects of the Ethiopian Grand Renaissance Dam for water levels in their home areas. [size=dozens]
On 24 February 2020, three armed men abducted, raped and beat a young IDP girl in Garsila IDP camp (Central Darfur state). She was found on the roadside the following day.

On 24 February 2020, employees staged a protest at the Kenana Sugar Factor (Sennar state) against the failure of plant managers to reinstate those who were dismissed during the uprising beginning Dec 2018, and to address pay discrepancies in the factory. [size=no report]

On 24 February 2020, unknown gunmen killed a prosecutor in Muglad (West Kordofan state). There is no further information.

On or around 23 February 2020, employees of the National Forestry Authority demonstrated at the Ministry of Agriculture in Khartoum, calling for the dismissal of the Directors of the authority, in a dispute which is linked to cronyism and the awarding of land during the years of Omar al-Bashir's presidency. [size=no report]

On 23 February 2020, teachers began a sit-in protest in Ed Duweim (Northern state), calling for the dismissal of the Director of Education and other senior officials in the area, due to their links with the former Al-Ingaz regime. [size=no report]

On 22 February 2020, armed pastoralists shot and wounded a man at the village Tamarbol El Jemayel north-east of Zalingei town (Central Darfur state), and stole 23 cows. Some of the livestock were rescued, and four of the attackers were arrested.
On 22 February 2020, three PDF paramilitaries shot a man near Rashad town (South Kordofan state), for unclear reasons. The victim died of his wounds shortly afterwards.
On 22 February 2020, armed pastoralists wounded a farmer in Nomoua south of Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), after hitting her with rifle butts. There is no further information.

actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces

On 20 February 2020, thousands of Sudanese youth marched in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the reinstatement of army officers who joined FFC-organised protesters in April 2019, but who have now been dismissed. [size=thousands]

On 20 February 2020, demonstrators gathered in Saraf Omra (North Darfur state), protesting against fuel shortages and a lack of clear improvement in living conditions since the uprising began. They called for the dismissal of the executive director of Saraf Omra locality. [size=no report]

On 20 February 2020, thousands of Sudanese youth marched in Khartoum, calling for the reinstatement of army officers who joined FFC-organised demonstrators in April 2019, but who have now been dismissed. Police used tear gas, batons and live rounds, injuring between 19 and 53, at least one of whom had a gunshot wound. Police claimed that 4 of their own officers (later revised upwards to 60) were wounded. [size=thousands]
On 19 February 2020, two civilians were killed by unknown gunmen near Besouti in Mukjar locality (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.

On 17 February 2020, demonstrators gathered in Dibebad in Al Qoz locality (South Kordofan state), following the distribution of incorrect medicines to children in the area, which caused illnesses among them. On 30 January 2020, protesters marched in Khartoum, calling for the rapid civilianisation of executive positions (especially state governors) and of the legislature. Note that some Resistance Committees refused to participate, stating that good progress was being made. [size=large]

On 29 January 2020, residents of An Nahud (West Kordofan state) began a sit-in protest, calling for a redistribution of land in their area, and improvements to its development potential. [size=no report]

On or before 29 January 2020, demonstrators (comprising members of the performing arts) demonstrated in Nyala (South Darfur state), calling for the library and theatre to be returned to public ownership, and restored to their original functions. [size=no report]

On 29 January 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed a civilian as he walked with his brother between Khor-Eldeleib and Ambeir in Abu Kershola locality (no geographic information found, coordinates for Abu Kershola, South Kordofan state, used at geoprec2). The brother survived unharmed. The source alludes to increased PDF paramilitary activity in the area as being linked to the killing, but actor1 coded as UAG pending further information.

On 29 January 2020, a PDF paramilitary killed two civilian and wounded three at a well near Abu Kershola in Abu Kershola locality (South Kordofan state). The attack is in revenge for a prior attack on the soldiers' house, which is linked to a dispute between two families. Authorities have not arrested the perpetrator.

On 29 January 2020, residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) staged a large gathering to commemorate the massacre of protesters on 29 Jan 2005, calling for the perpetrators to face justice. [size=large]

On 28 January 2020, armed pastoralists attacked the house of a farmer in Darraba (Sunta locality, South Darfur state), after he had cleared them from his land earlier that day. The farmer escaped the attack, though some of his animals were shot. Police have arrested the attackers.

On 28 January 2020, unknown attackers burned three dwellings and looted property in the area of Teranga, causing residents to flee to Sortony IDP camp in Kebkabiya locality (coordinates for Kebkabiya town, North Darfur state, used at geoprec2, on the assumption the location is in the same administrative unit). There is no further information.

On 28 January 2020, students aged 13 and 16 were abducted as they travelled north of Saraf Omra (North Darfur state, coordinates used) by an unknown group. Their bodies were found dumped in Saraf Omra town on 31 Jan. One person has been arrested so far in connection with the killings.
On 27 January 2020, Ethiopian refugees protested in Khartoum, having been denied their rights as refugees due to a lack of proper registration. [size=no report]
On 27 January 2020, journalists demonstrated in Khartoum, against a closure of a newspaper with (disputed) links to the Al-Ingaz regime of Omar el Bashir. [size=no report]

On 26 January 2020, residents of El Jebelain (White Nile state) demonstrated against a lack of affordable bread; poor basic services; and for increased civilianisation of the administrative apparatus following the uprising. [size=no report]

On 26 January 2020, dozens of protesters marched in Khartoum in protest at allegations made against a UAE-based security company, which has been accused of sending Sudanese recruits to Libya or Yemen, rather than stationing them in the UAE itself (as was reportedly advertised). [size=dozens]
On 26 January 2020, protesters marched in Khartoum following the killing of around 32 civilians in Abyei on 29 Jan, calling for justice for the victims. [size=no report]

On 22 and 23 January 2020, rioters plundered the Small Farmers Association offices in Kebkabiya town (North Darfur state), claiming the association was being run by the 'deep state' of the Al Ingaz regime, and was not fairly distributing emergency relief to victims of floods (note the items looted included generators and office equipment, and not food). The looters also burned documents belonging to the association. [size=no report]

On 23 January 2020, SAF arrested around 80 individuals who had been recruited into an unknown rebel movement which the source indicates had been established as a basis for the commander of the group to enter peace talks in Juba. The arrests occurred in Al Habara in Sunta locality and Al Bishiga in El Radoom locality (no geographic information found; coordinates for Al Fifi, El Radoom locality, South Darfur state, used at geoprec2).
On 22 January 2020, six unknown gunmen attacked two civilians in Al Abbasiya (South Kordofan state), shooting both after robbing them. One of the victims survived, though the other died at the scene.

On or before 22 January 2020, employees of the vetinerary services lab protested in Khartoum, calling for greater resources for their research, and for an end to encroachments on lands owned by the lab. [size=no report]

On 22 and 23 January 2020, rioters plundered the Small Farmers Association offices in Kebkabiya town (North Darfur state), claiming the association was being run by the 'deep state' of the Al Ingaz regime, and was not fairly distributing emergency relief to victims of floods (note the items looted included generators and office equipment, and not food). The looters also burned documents belonging to the association. [size=no report]

source: Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan); UNSC; Radio Miraya; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 22 January 2020, the Ngok Dinka village of Kolom in the disputed Abyei area was attacked by Misseriya pastoralists, resulting in 33 fatalities, 24 injuries and 15 child abductions (as well as 22 dwellings being torched). Unverified accusations of Sudanese military and/or Popular Defence Force paramilitary involvement have been made by the administrator of the area. 5 Misseriya have been arrested by UNISFA peacekeepers. 4,000 were displaced between attacks in Nainai and Kolom on 22 January. Update: 6 abducted children have been released.

On 21 January 2020, a soldier threw a grenade into a wedding ceremony in a suburb of Khartoum North, killing 9 or 10 (9 fatalities coded) including the soldier, and wounding around 70. The attack was reported to be motivated by jealousy on the part of the soldier.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 21 January 2020, SAF, RSF and Police forces clashed with an unknown group who attacked a wedding in Silo the previous day at an unspecified location (coordinates for Silo, Marshing locality, South Darfur state, used at geoprec2). Two police and one soldier were wounded, and three of the perpetrators of the attack were arrested.

On or before 21 January 2020, IDPs protested in Krinding IDP camp (West Darfur state) following a visit from the military governor to the area (which has been severely affected by violence in late December). RSF evacuated the governor from the area (event coded as Peaceful Demonstration, as no actual violence appears to have taken place, despite the tone of the source). [size=no report]

On 20 January 2020, SAF soldiers shot dead a civilian who was in a vehicle near El Gergaf (Wad El Helew locality, Kassala state). Conflicting accounts are given as to whether the civilian was ordered to stop. Several soldiers have been arrested.
On 20 January 2020, protesters gathered in Khartoum to stage a large protest over shortages of fuel, which are attributed to elements of the 'deep state' linked to the Al Ingaz regime. [size=large]

On 20 January 2020, protesters gathered in Nyala (South Darfur state) to protest shortages of fuel, which are attributed to elements of the 'deep state' linked to the Al Ingaz regime. [size=no report]

On 20 January 2020, protesters gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state) to protest shortages of fuel, which are attributed to elements of the 'deep state' linked to the Al Ingaz regime. [size=no report]

On 20 January 2020, an unknown armed group attacked IDPs at a wedding in Silo (Marshang locality, South Darfur state), killing five at the wedding (with three others later dying of their injuries) and wounding around another 22.

On or before 20 January 2020, hundreds of demonstrators gathered in Kass (South Darfur state) to demonstrate against high bread prices and the high costs of basic services. Some of the demonstrators pelted stones at bakeries in the town. [size=hundreds]

On 20 January 2020, protesters blocked a road (likely between Khasm El Girba and Kassala town, coordinates for Fasher, Seteet locality, Kassala state used at geoprec2), following the killing of a civilian by soldiers the same day. Protesters had earlier gathered outside the hospital, likely in Khasm El Girba (one event coded). [size=no report]

On 19 and 20 January or 20 and 21 January 2020 (two events coded at time prec2), protesters (including students) gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to protest shortages of fuel, which are attributed to elements of the 'deep state' linked to the Al Ingaz regime. [size=no report]

On 19 January 2020, teachers demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for the dismissal of directors of education who are linked to the Al Ingaz regime of deposed President Omar al Bashir. [size=no report]
On 19 January 2020, hundreds of students demonstrated in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), calling for an end to shortages of bread. [size=hundreds]

On 19 January 2020, a suspected Ngok Dinka militia attacked Misseriya pastoralists at Nainai in the disputed Abyei area, resulting in three Misseriya being killed. 4,000 were displaced between attacks in Nainai and Kolom on 22 January.

On 19 and 20 January or 20 and 21 January 2020 (two events coded at time prec2), protesters (including students) gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) to protest shortages of fuel, which are attributed to elements of the 'deep state' linked to the Al Ingaz regime. [size=no report]

As reported on 19 January 2020 (and coded as 18 Jan at time prec2), bandits attacked pastoralists at a well in Kullu village (North Darufr state). In the firefight, 2 bandits were killed and 2 wounded, whilst one pastoralist was wounded.
On 16 January 2020, three unknown gunmen raped a young girl as she was carrying food to her father, at an unspecified location near Tawila (North Darfur state, coordinates used).

assoc_actor_1: Pastoralists (Sudan); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 16 January 2020, armed pastoralists (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) alongside men in military uniform (presumed to be RSF, and coded as such) attacked four villages in the Jebel Marrah area likely near Rokoro (coordinates for Mari, Central Darfur, used at geoprec2). There were no reports of fatalities, though 150 families were displaced, and the villages looted.
On 14 January 2020, students (including medical students) from three universities protested in Khartoum at the poor quality of their education. [size=no report]
On 14 January 2020, three unknown gunmen shot dead a civilian at his home at El Fayd (South Kordofan state)

actor1: Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
source: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Radio Tamazuj; AFP; Sudan TV; AP
notes: On 14 January 2020, former NISS soldiers from the Operations Authority division mutined, firing weapons in the air in several NISS bases in Khartoum and Khartoum North. SAF and RSF re-tookthe bases, with a firefight breaking out in at least some locations (events coded as Battles). A teenager was wounded in the Shambat are of Khartoum North, from a stray bullet.
On 14 January 2020, unknown attackers seriously wounded a male IDP at Hasahisa camp (Central Darfur state). There is no clear motivation for the attack.

actor1: Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 14 January 2020, former NISS soldiers from the Operations Authority division mutinied in El Obeid (North Kordofan state). The source notes that there clashes between former NISS soldiers and serving RSF paramilitaries, but does not mention whether there were fatalities.

actor1: Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
source: Al Rakoba; Sudan TV; AFP; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga; AP
notes: On 14 January 2020, former NISS soldiers from the Operations Authority division mutined, firing weapons in the air in several NISS bases in Khartoum and Khartoum North. SAF and RSF re-took the bases, with a firefight breaking out in at least some locations (events coded as Battles). Two government soldiers were killed and two wounded in Khartoum, whilst a family home was hit by a shell in the Soba area of Khartoum, killing three.

On 13 January 2020, medical students protested in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), following the decision by the state government to transfer the Dean of the medical college at the local University. [size=no report]
On 13 January 2020, unknown attackers fired upon a family travelling between Kutrum and Nertiti (Central Darfur, coordinates for Turru used at geoprec2), wounding a teenager.

On 13 January 2020, militiamen on camels (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked two commercial vehicles on the road between Nertiti and Jildo near Gurnei village (coordinates for Guldo, North Darfur state, used at geoprec2). The attackers robbed the victims. There is no report of injuries or fatalities.

On 12 January 2020, unknown gunmen killed an IDP farmer in the area of the farms at Judu 3, 3km south of Saraf Omra town (coordinates for Fassi, Central Darfur state, used at geoprec2). The attackers then mutilated the body of the victim.

On 12 January 2020, IDPs demonstrated in Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), in a protest which appears linked to the ongoing peace talks in Juba, and which prevented delegates to the talks from being selected. [size=no report]

On or around 12 January 2020, five 'militiamen' (coded as Darfur communal militia) attacked an elderly displaced person at Fata Borno camp (North Darfur), wounding him. There is no further information.

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
assoc_actor_2: NCP: National Congress Party; Police Forces of Sudan (2019-)
notes: On 11 January 2020, supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party marched in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), but were intercepted by a counter-demonstration involving FFC members. Conflicting reports suggest that NCP demonstrators (and potentially, armed NCP supporters) as well as police attacked counter-demonstrators, wounding between 7 and 11 (2 seriously) using firearms and tear gas. [size=at least 7]

On 9 January 2020, striking port workers demonstrated in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for the release of the Shipping and Unloading Association director, who had been arrested in relation to a killing the previous day. [size=no report]

On 9 January 2020, gunmen on horses (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) attacked Seraf Jidad (West Darfur state), killing two brothers, and seriously injuring their sister and mother. The attackers then looted livestock and money.

On 9 January 2020, police and a local search group (coded as unidentified communal militia) arrested five gunmen on horses (coded as Darfur pastoralist militia) who had earlier attacked Seraf Jidad village (West Darfur, coordinates used at geoprec2). Additional militiamen arrived and attacked the police and search group, and released the five captives. The source does not mention if there were any casualties.

On 8 January 2020, clashes resumed in Port Sudan (Red Sea state) between two unspecified groups (coded as Beni Amir and Nuba militias, given that violence in Port Sudan has involved these groups over the past months) armed with bladed weapons, causing five injuries.

assoc_actor_1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
notes: On 7 January 2020, protesters (including supporters of SLM/A-Al Nur rebels) marched in Khartoum, calling for the government to extradite deposed ruler Omar el Bashir and his associates for trial at the ICC, and for an end to violence in Darfur. [size=large]

assoc_actor_1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); Refugees/IDPs (Sudan)
notes: On 7 January 2020, protesters (including IDPs and supporters of SLM/A-Al Nur rebels) marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state), calling for the government to extradite deposed ruler Omar el Bashir and his associates for trial at the ICC; for arms to be collected from militias in Darfur; and for an investigation into the perpetrators of the recent violence in West Darfur. [size=hundreds]

assoc_actor_1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction); Refugees/IDPs (Sudan)

[size=hundreds]
On 7 January 2020, protesters marched in Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=hundreds]

On 5 January 2020, protesters staged two demonstrations (one event coded) in Kadugli (South Kordofan state), calling for resistance committee members who had been arrested on public order charges to be released (and who were released following the protests). [size=no report]

From 2-4 January 2020, Beni Amir and Nuba groups clashed in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). 2 were killed on 2 Jan; 6 on 3 Jan; and 6 on 4 Jan, and between 115 and 127 were injured across three days of fighting. The current clashes are attributed to the killing of a man during a fight with another man, who was later arrested.

On 4 January 2020, a vehicle carrying civilians was attacked by armed gunmen, killing four (including a child) and wounding three. The incident occurred on the road between Nyala and Burma, with the source implying the event to have taken place near Buram (South Darfur state, coordinates used at geoprec2).

From 2-4 January 2020, Beni Amir and Nuba groups clashed once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). 2 were killed on 2 Jan; 6 on 3 Jan; and 6 on 4 Jan. Between 115 and 127 were injured across three days of fighting. The current clashes are attributed to the killing of a man during a fight with another man, who was later arrested.
On or before 3 January 2020, female students demonstrated in Khartoum, following repeated thefts in the area. Demonstrators burned tires, blocking part of Al-Ghaba street. [size=no report]

On 2 January 2020, demonstrators (including IDPs from West Darfur) gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North (two events coded) to protest against the violence in West Darfur from 27-30 Dec, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

From 2-4 January 2020, Beni Amir and Nuba groups clashed once again in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). 2 were killed on 2 Jan; 6 on 3 Jan; and 6 on 4 Jan. Between 115 and 127 were injured across three days of fighting. The current clashes are attributed to the killing of a man during a fight with another man, who was later arrested.

On 2 January 2020, demonstrators (including IDPs from West Darfur) gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North (two events coded) to protest against the violence in West Darfur from 27-30 Dec, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

On 2 January 2020, female demonstrators marched in Khartoum in an event organised by around 60 women's civil society organisations and political movements, calling for the government to sign and implment the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. [size=hundreds]

actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 1 January 2020, IDPs blocked the road between El Geneina town and the airport at Ardamata IDP camp (West Darfur state) following three days of violence in the area, preventing the motorcade carrying senior officials (including PM Hamdock and Deputy Chair of the Sovereign Council 'Hemedti'). RSF dispersed the crowds. The means through which the road was blocked are not specified (actor1 coded as protesters). [size=hundreds]

On 1 January 2020, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum to protest against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=hundreds]

On 1 January 2020, gunmen on camels and horses (coded as Darfur Pastoralist militia) attacked Terinja village (North Darfur state; coordinates for Sortony IDP camp used at geoprec2), displacing at least 70 families. There are no reports of casualties or fatalities, and the attackers looted the village.

On 1 January 2020, IDPs in Zamzam camp (North Darfur state) demonstrated against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

On 1 January 2020, IDPs in Gereida camp (South Darfur state) demonstrated against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]

On 1 January 2020, demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani (El Gazira state) to protest against the violence in West Darfur over the previous three days, which had mainly been led by Arab-identified Maaliya against Darfrui Masalit. [size=no report]
On 1 January 2020,unknown attackers armed with bladed weapons attacked doctors at a hospital in Omdurman, wounding one. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 1 January 2020, unknown attackers armed with bladed weapons were reported to have attacked civilians in the area of Freedom Square during independence day celebrations (Note that this event is separate to an event in which women were attacked at the square on the same day). Police dispersed the attackers using tear gas.

On 1 January 2020, unknown attackers armed with bladed weapons attacked five women in Freedom Square in Khartoum, during independence day celebrations. Three women were injured. The motive for the attack is unclear.

On 31 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked the police HQ and legislative council building in El Geneina (West Darfur state), killing four police and wounding one other. Property (including weapons and a police vehicle) were then stolen.
On 31 December 2019, Maaliya pastoralists attacked a police outpost at Atia (West Darfur state), killing two police, before looting the area.

On 30 and 31 December 2019, the Awlad Gaid and Mansour sections of the Misseriya clashed in the areas of Tebeldina and Abga Rajel (South Darfur state, coordinates for Tebeldina used at geoprec2). Six were killed and five injured; RSF paramilitaries broke up the clashes. Two events coded with fatalities spread across both.

On 30 December 2019, protesters from the Maaliya ethnic group (some of whom were related to a victim (or victims) of violence the previous day) demonstrated in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the perpetrators of the killing to be handed over to them within one day. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces; Pastoralists (Sudan)
source: Darfur 24; UNAMID; UNOCHA; Sudan Tribune; Radio Dabanga
notes: On 30 December 2019, serious fighting was reported in Krinding IDP camp and multiple areas in and around El Geneina city (West Darfur state) including Delmengi and Majmari villages. Attacks led by Maaliya pastoralists and RSF paramilitaries against Masalit Darfuris (including Masalit IDPs), though some fatalities on the side of the Maaliya are reported. UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries), of which 47 fatalities have been coded to events in Krinding camp and El Geneina (the epicentre of the violence, with the remainder of estimated fatalities spread across smaller events). Event at Krinding IDP camp coded as armed clash to allow for a small number of Maaliya fatalities which occurred.

UNAMID estimates say at least 65 were killed and over 50 injured (other reports suggest significantly higher injuries). Three events coded with three fatalities each (other fatalities from UNAMID estimates spread across separate events), with coordinates for Durti (West Darfur) used for Sultan House camp.

On 30 December 2019, protesters (including members of the teachers union) gathered at the court in Omdurman, in solidarity with a teacher who was killed in Kassala in January by NISS agents. Police dispersed the crowds with tear gas, which reportedly led to the death of an asthmatic civilian. [size=hundreds]

On 30 December 2019, unknown gunmen abducted an elderly IDP as he travelled from Nertiti to Jebel Marrah (coordinates for Nertiti, Central Darfur state, used at geoprec2). The fate of the man is unknown.

On 29 December 2019, residents of Babanussa (West Kordofan state) began a sit-in protest, after plans for upgrading the areas roads were altered, bypassing the town. [size=dozens]

On 29 December 2019, seven Maaliya pastoralist were wounded by Masalit residents of the Kriding IDP camp (West Darfur state, actor coded as Masalit militia) when they went to retrieve the body of a Maaliya man who was killed in a fight earlier that day, according to the Arab Youth Committee.

On 29 December 2019, attackers (described as 'Janjaweed', but coded as Maaliya pastoralist militia) attacked El Geneiena hospital (West Darfur state), killing one, and assaulting several medical staff.

On 29 December 2019, Darfuri protesters gathered in the three cities of Greater Khartoum, calling for justice for the victims of the Al-Ingaz regime living in Sudan's peripheries, and for deposed President Omar el Bashir to be tried at the ICC. On 29 December 2019, workers of the El Salam cement factory protested in Rabak (White Nile state), calling for improved pay, worker safety, and an end to unjust management practices at the plant. [size=no report]
On 28 December 2019, unknown persons torched three churches in Bout (Blue Nile state). They then burned them down a second time after they had been rebuilt, on 16 January 2020 (one event coded).

On 26 December 2019, two female Masalit IDPs were killed by Arab-identified militiamen (presumed to be Maaliya) as they were gathering firewood at Sisi camp in Kreinik locality (West Darfur state). There is no clear motive for the attack. Residents of Sisi IDP camp later apprehended the attackers.

On or after 26 December 2019, Masalit IDPs protested against the recent killing of two women near Sisi, blocking the road from Sisi to El Geniena at an unspecified location along the road (presumed to be at or near Sisi, West Darfur state). It is unclear how long the protest lasted for. [size=no report]

On or before 26 December 2019, rioters burned a civil administration office and torched several cars at El Geneina (West Darfur state), after a female IDP was injured in a hit and run incident. The demonstrators also stole four firearms. 'Regular forces' (coded as army) dispersed the crowds with gunfire. [size=no report]
On 25 December 2019, an Amhara militia fired upon Sudanese civilians at Wad Kholy (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state), killing one, and wounding four. The motive for the attack is unclear.

On 25 December 2019, protesters marched in Khartoum to commemorate the anniversary of mass marches in the city in December 2018, calling for the removal of the remnants of the Bashir regime and justice for those who suffered under it; the consolidation of civilian rule; an investigation into military and paramilitary sources of finance; and an end to economic hardship. [size=thousands]
On 23 December 2019, Darfuri students from Tawila locality demonstrated at the Ministry of Justice in Khartoum, following a spate of attacks by armed pastoralists in their home area. [size=no report]

On 20 December 2019, journalists from the dismantled Sudanese Journalists Union (which was linked to the feared NISS agency under the Bashir regime) held a sit-in protest in Khartoum, after the organisation was disbanded on 14 Dec. The protest was boycotted by most journalists based in the capital. [size=40]
