On 18 or 19 December 2019, demonstrators carried the body of a sheep farmer killed at Abu Sakin to the governor's house at El Fasher (North Darfur state), in protest at insecurity in the area. [size=no report]
On 18 December 2019, unknown assailants killed a sheep farmer as he was grazing his sheep near Abu Sakin (North Darfur state) using sticks. There is no clear motive for the attack.

On or around 18 December 2019, rioters set fire to police stations at two unspecified locations in West and Central Darfur state, following the death of a child in an incident involving the police in Murnei (West Darfur state). One event coded in Murnei at geoprec2, and another in Zalingei (North Darfur) coded at geoprec3. [size=no report]
On or around 18 December 2019, police fired upon a vehicle that did not stop at a checkpoint in Murnei (West Darfur state), killing a child in the process.

On or around 18 December 2019, rioters set fire to police stations at two unspecified locations in West and Central Darfur state, following the death of a child in an incident involving the police in Murnei (West Darfur state). One event coded in Murnei at geoprec2, and another in Zalingei (North Darfur) coded at geoprec3. [size=no report]

On 17 December 2019, farmers from Kalamindo locality demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), against trespassing, theft and damage to crops caused by pastoralists. The demonstrators also marched with the body of a slain farmer (killed in Korma) in El Fasher (North Darfur state) calling for justice and improved security in the area. The source mentions that the farmers blocked a road, but does not specify the means by which this was done (actor1 coded as protesters). [size=no report]

On 17 December 2019, students from the University of Ed Daein (East Darfur state) demonstrated following the death of a student, who drowned by falling into a water tank at her dormitory. The students accused the administration of negligence. [size=large]

On or around 17 December 2019, unknown gunmen attacked a police colonel, his family, and his bodygaurds (actor2 coded as police) at an unspecified location on the road between Buram and Nyala (South Darfur state, coordinates for Buram used at geoprec2). The attackers beat his family, and stole from his entourage.

On or before 17 December 2019, armed pastoralists shot dead a farmer and wounded another in the al Ghanam area near Korma (North Darfur state, coordinates used at geoprec2), when he attempted to clear their animals from his land. Police and a local rescue team arrested one of the attackers.
On 16 December 2019, protesters gathered in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the military governor to be removed, following allegations of extensive corruption. [size=thousands]

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Sudan (2019-) General Intelligence Service
assoc_actor_2: Journalists (Sudan); Former Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On 16 December 2019, Sudanese authorities continued their dismantlement of the Bashir al-Ingaz regime, seizing the assets of several NCP-affiliated unions, and with the GIS (formerly NISS) dissolving three media houses linked to the notorious former intelligence agency (the SMC, Sudan Vision, and the Khartoum Electronic Media Centre).

Around 15 December 2019 (month of), three Sudanese were reported to have been killed and four injured at the hands of an Amhara militia at an unspecified location in El Fashaga locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Jebel Alokdi]. 200 head of cattle were also stolen.

actor2: UNAMID: United Nations/African Union Hybrid Operation in Darfur (2007-)
notes: Looting: Around 15 December 2019 (month of), looters ransacked the UNAMID base at Otash IDP Camp (Nyala Shimal locality, South Darfur state). There is no further information.

During the months of November and December 2019, a report by Darfuri farmer claimed that 20 farmers had been killed and over 30 wounded in a series of attacks in and around Jebel Marra (coordinates for Um Sayala, Dali, Koto, and Kadareik in North and Central Darfur states used at geoprec2; other locations mentioned include Karfala, Um Laouta, and Tangarara). 18 fatalities total coded (two fatalities already in the ACLED dataset deducted), spread across four events at time prec3 ( 4 each).

On 14 December 2019, supporters of President Omar al-Bashir and his banned NCP party marched in Khartoum, in opposition to the dismantlement of the Bashir regime, and to his jail sentence handed down that same day. [size=3,000]

On 14 December 2019, deposed President Omar al-Bashir was sentenced to two years imprisonment in a correctional institute for elderly prisoners, on charges of corruption. Bashir also faces charges relating to the 1989 coup that brought him to power, as well as violence against protesters.
On 13 December 2019, residents of Al Kereinkik (West Darfur state) demonstrated against corruption, violence and a lack of bread and fuel. [size=hundreds]
On 13 December 2019, residents of Habila (West Darfur state) demonstrated against corruption, violence and a lack of bread and fuel. [size=hundreds]
On 13 December 2019, residents of Kondobei (West Darfur state) demonstrated against corruption, violence and a lack of bread and fuel. [size=hundreds]

On 13 December 2019, protesters gathered in El Galabat (Gedaref state), to protest against attacks by Ethiopian shifta in the area. The source says that demonstrators blocked the road to the border, but does not specify the means through which this was done. [size=no report]

On 13 December 2019, demonstrators marched in Khartoum, in opposition to the 'Green March' to be organised the following day by supporters of deposed President Omar al-Bashir and his banned NCP party. [size=large]

On 12 December 2019, students marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling for affordable bread, improvement to transportation in the city, and for improvements to the University of El Fasher. [size=no report]

On or before 12 December 2019, protesters marched to the governors office in El Fasher (North Darfur state), carrying the bodies of the two deceased men from the clash at Tabra on 10 Dec, in protest at insecurity in the region. [size=no report]

On 12 December 2019, Nuba youth attacked members of the Beni Amer clan in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), sparking clashes between the groups. 29 were reported to have been injured, two seriously. The initial attack occurred after the postponement of a court trial which was to prosecute those involved in previous rounds of violence between the two groups in the city.

On or around 12 December 2019, students of the University of the Holy Quran and Islamic Sciences in Khartoum began a sit-in protest, calling for an end for segregation between male and female students, and for a toning down of the Islamic content of the university. [size=no report]
On 12 December 2019, a police officer raped a 16 year-old girl in Geissan (Blue Nile state). Police have refused to acknowledge the event.

On 11 December 2019, armed pastoralists blocked a road near Sortony IDP camp (North Darfur state) in protest against an attack that killed a pastoralist. They threatened to attack the camp unless residents (whom they allege to be harbouring rebels) turn over the perpetrators of the rebel ttack which killed a pastoralist. [size=no report]

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
notes: On or before 11 December 2019, an unspecified rebel group (presumed to be SLM/A Al-Nur rebels, given their presence in the area) shot dead an armed pastoralist at an area implied to be close to Sortony (North Darfur state).

On 11 December 2019, armed pastoralists shot at three female farmers after they attempted to clear the pastoralists from their land, in the area of Dobo Umda (North Darfur state). Two of the farmers were wounded, and the other is missing (fatality precision 2 used).
On 11 December 2019, protesters gathered in Tawila (North Darfur state), to demonstrate against attacks by armed pastoralists in the area. [size=no report]
On 10 December 2019, an Amhara militia killed a Sudanese civilian (likely a farmer) at Barakat Norein (El Quresha locality, Gedaref state).

On 10 December 2019, armed pastoralists clashed with a local farmer self-defence militia (seemingly accompanied by SAF) at Tabra, 15km north-west of Tawila (North Darfur state; no geographic information found, coordinates for Tawila used at geoprec2). One farmer militiaman and one soldier were killed, and two others wounded.

On 9 and 10 December 2019, student supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party attacked left-wing students at the Islamic University at Omdurman, with several students wounded in the clashes. The source indicates that police dispersed the groups, although this is unclear. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change; Labour Group (Sudan)
notes: On or around 9 December 2019, protesters (including FFC members) demonstrated against arbitrary dismissals of employees of the Kenana Sugar Factory at Kenana (Sennar state), and for a restructuring of the management of the factory. Police dispersed protesters with batons and tear gas. 10 activists were arrested. [size=no report]
On 9 December 2019, an Amhara militia abducted three Sudanese civilians at an unspecified location in Eastern El Galabat locality (Gedaref state) [coded to Sundus].

On 9 December 2019, demonstrators burned tires on the main road between Wad Medani and Khartoum near Wadelmajzoub and Al Sawar in El Gazira state (no geographic information found; coordinates for Wad Medani, El Gazira state, used at geoprec3), in opposition to attempts by local government to put a rubbish dump in a residential area. Police beat demonstrators, wounding an unspecified number. One event coded. [size=no report]

On 9 December 2019, demonstrators burned tires on roads in Kassala (Kassala state), in demonstration against an attack on civilians by soldiers two days prior. Police attempted to disperse the demonstrators, wounding five. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 9 December 2019, gunmen in military uniform (presumed to be RSF paramilitaries, given their presence in the area) attacked farms in the area of Khor Ramla (Central Darfur), injuring six farmers, and gang-raping a 16 year-old girl.
On 9 December 2019, secondary school students marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), in opposition to high prices for food and transportation. [size=no report]

On 9 and 10 December 2019, student supporters of the outlawed National Congress Party attacked left-wing students at the Islamic University at Omdurman, with several students wounded in the clashes. The source indicates that police dispersed the groups, although this is unclear. [size=no report]
On 8 December 2019, protesters gathered in Kebkabiya (North Darfur state), to protest against insecurity caused by RSF paramilitaries and armed pastoralists. [size=large]

On 8 December 2019, Arab nomadic militiamen (presumed to be Misseriya militiamen, and coded as such) attacked the Lou area of Abyei, killing three Ngok Dinka civilians. A further three civilians are missing (fatality precision 2 used).
On 7 December 2019, SAF attacked civilians at Abu Gamal (Kassala state), wounding 15. The reasons for the attack are unclear.
On 7 December 2019, armed pastoralists attacked farmers at Shoba (North Darufr state), wounding 20 (the source notes 12 female farmers were seriously wounded).

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 7 December 2019, RSF paramilitaries abducted and tortured an agricultural committee specialist at their HQ south of Kebkabiya (North Darfur state). There is no clear motive for the attack.

On 6 December 2019, armed pastoralists clashed with police at Galala village in western Kreinik locality (no geographic information found, coordinates for Derjeil, West Darfur state, used at geoprec2), resulting in two civilians being wounded in the crossfire.
On 6 December 2019, armed pastoralists attacked Al Kereinik (West Darfur state), killing a farmer in the process, and wounding several others.

On or around 6 December 2019, academics from the University of Ribat in Khartoum protested against the dismissal of employees during the national uprising; the continued presence of Bashir-era officials in higher education institutions; and for the dismantlement of the old state. [size=small]
On 6 December 2019, residents of Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur state) protested against rising insecurity and human rights abuses in the area, following a spate of incidents. [size=no report]
On 5 December 2019, unidentified gunmen killed a civilian in Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur state), before looting his body. There is no further information.

On 5 December 2019, unspecified militiamen (coded as Darfur Pastoralist militia, given the contextual information in the source) attacked Lia village (South Darfur state), burning crops, and firing in the air to scare residents.

On 4 December 2019, PDF militiamen shot dead a farmer at Shag El Kitir village (South Kordofan state, approximate coordinates 9km north-west of Um Barambita used at geoprec2), after he refused to hand over his produce to them. No action has been taken by authorities.

On 4 December 2019, two groups of unidentified gunmen clashed in the market at Kass (South Darfur state). Four civilians - including a teenager - were killed in the crossfire. The gunmen left the market once security forces arrived.
On 3 December 2019, IDPs demonstrated in Zam Zam camp (North Darfur state), against attacks by armed pastoralists, and at the shrotages of essential goods and services in the camp. [size=no report]
On 3 December 2019, protesters marched in Kutum (North Darfur state), calling for the disarmament of armed pastoralists, and restrictions on their access to grazing land. [size=no report]
On 3 December 2019, a 13 year-old girl was raped by an armed pastoralist south of Mali village (Central Darfur state).

source: Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 3 December 2019, relatives of those who were killed in the course of the uprising in Sudan marched to various political and judicial institutions - including the President's Palace - in Khartoum, calling for justice. [size=thousands]

On 2 December 2019, journalists belonging to the Sudanese Journalists Network demonstrated at the Ministry of Culture and Information at Khartoum, calling for officials from the Bashir regime to be removed from office. [size=no report]

On 2 December 2019, armed pastoralist fired upon farmers who were attempted to clear them from their land in the vicinity of El Hamra (North Darfur state). Several farmers were wounded, five seriously. Local authorities and Resistance Committees apprehended one of the attackers with his weapon, and seized 2,000 head of cattle from him.

On or around 1 December 2019, two or more unknown groups clashed using bladed weapons in Jabal Aulia (Khartoum state), prompting the intervention of security services. The source does not mention whether there were fatalities or injuries.

On 1 December 2019, demonstrators - including students - marched and burned tires in Wad Medani (El Gazira state), in opposition to the lack of bread and transportation in the city, and calling for the dismissals of the military governor of the state, and the head of the GIS stationed in El Gazira. [size=thousands]

On 1 December 2019, 'militiamen' (coded as Darfur Communal Militia) shot and seriously wounded two men in Korkei village of Sirba locality (no geographic info found; coordinates for Sirba, West Darfur state, used at geoprec2).
On 1 December 2019, protesters demonstrated against increasing bread prices in Nyala (South Darfur state). Police dispersed the protesters, beating an unspecified number. [size=no report]
On or around 1 December 2019, police assaulted two doctors at a hospital in Khartoum. Staff of the hospital went on strike following the attack.

On or around 1 December 2019, relative and mourners of a farmer killed by pastoralists on 30 November travelled to the administrative HQ in El Fasher (North Darfur state), in protest at his killing. [size=no report]

On 1 December 2019, unidentified gunmen shot dead a civilian at an unspecified location between Kass and Um Laouta (South Darfur state, coordinates for Kass used at geoprec2). There is no clear motive for the attack.

On or around 1 December 2019, armed pastoralists fired upon a vehicle carrying immunisation workers on the road between Kendede and Bir Daqiq (West Darfur state, coordinates for Bir Daqiq used at geoprec2), wounding one health worker.

During the months of November and December 2019, a report by Darfuri farmer claimed that 20 farmers had been killed and over 30 wounded in a series of attacks in and around Jebel Marra (coordinates for Um Sayala, Dali, Koto, and Kadareik in North and Central Darfur states used at geoprec2; other locations mentioned include Karfala, Um Laouta, and Tangarara). 18 fatalities total coded (two fatalities already in the ACLED dataset deducted), spread across four events at time prec3.
On 30 November 2019, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer near Turr (North Darfur state, coordinates for Turra used at geoprec2).

On or around 30 November 2019, a soldier assaulted a female doctor at a hospital at an unspecified location in North Kordofan state (coordinates for state capital El Obeid used at geoprec2). Staff at the hospital went on strike following the attack.

On or around 30 November 2019, armed pastoralists attacked and injured two farmers at an unspecified area(s) of Mukjar locality (Central Darfur state, coordinates for Mukjar used at geoprec2). On 30 November or 1 December 2019, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer after he attempted to clear them from his farmland, near Tangarara (North Darfur state). The attackers have been arrested.

On 30 November 2019, demonstrators marched to the Cabinet Office and Public Prosecutors Office in Khartoum, demanding justice for those who have died in the course of the uprising, and for greater efforts to be made to keep the revolution on track, and to continue the dismantlement of the NCP. On 29 November 2019, gunmen riding motorbikes and camels attacked the village of Groma (West Darfur state), wounding two women and two school children. There is no clear motive for the attack.
On or around 28 November 2019, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer near Gokar (West Darfur state), after he attempted to clear them from his land.

On 28 November 2019, armed pastoralists attacked the town of Kondobei (West Darfur state), wounding four. The attackers burned dwellings, and looted livestock, and was in retaliation for a firefight between pastoralists and police the previous day.

On 28 November 2019, armed pastoralists shot and seriously wounded three farmers (two female) at their farms in the area of Tawila (North Darfur state), after the farmers attempted to clear the pastoralists from their land.

On October 14th, armed pastoralists shot and killed a farmer near Abu Gamra (North Darfur state), after he attempted to save his crops from the armed men's camels.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On 5 September 2019, RSF paramilitaries attacked Golo (Rokoro locality, Central Darfur state), killing one civilian and wounding three others.

On September 4th, supporters of RAC leader Musa Hilal called for his release at a demonstration at Damrat El Sheikh Abdelbagi (North Darfur state, coordinates for Kutum used at prec2). [size=no report]
On September 4th, demonstrators protested outside the Sudanese Professionals Association offices in Khartoum, calling for a transparent investigation into the June 3rd massacre. [size=no report]

On September 4th, professors and staff protested at the University of El Fasher, calling on the director of the university to prevent the allocation of university land plots to members of the RSF paramilitary. [size=dozens]
On September 4th, demonstrators protest against the increase in bread prices, and the manipulation of the sizes of bread loaves, in Kosti (White Nile state). [size=no report]

On September 4th, protesters continued a sit-in demonstration at Kalogi, South Kordofan, calling for gold mining companies who have caused harm to human and animal health through the use of chemicals to be removed from the area, and for compensation to be paid to those affected by the negative environmental effects of the mining. [size=no report]

On September 3rd, supporters of deposed leader Omar el-Bashir demonstrated outside Kober Prison in Khartoum North, calling for him and other senior members of his regime to be released. Police used batons and tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]
On September 3rd, demonstrators gathered at Central Omdurman Court, calling for justice for the killers of a teacher who died in Kassala in February. [size=hundreds]
On September 3rd, demonstrators marched in Khartoum and Khartoum North, to commemorate the victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=large]

On September 3rd, protesters began a sit-in demonstration (which lasted at least two days) at Kalogi, South Kordofan, calling for gold mining companies who have caused harm to human and animal health through the use of chemicals to be removed from the area, and for compensation to be paid to those affected by the negative environmental effects of the mining. [size=no report]
On September 3rd, demonstrators marched in Khartoum and Khartoum North, to commemorate the victims of the June 3rd massacre. [size=large]

On September 3rd, the two factions of the Sudan Revolutionary Front announced they were reunifying, and announced the appointment of SLM-TC head El Hadi Idriss Yahia as leader following the elapsing of Minni Minawi's term. Malik Agar is deputy, and Jibril Ibrahim secretary-general. On Sep 5th, President Salva Kiir announced that peace talks were to be held in Juba (involving most, though not all, Sudanese rebel groups), with government delegates scheduled to arrive on Sep 9th.

On September 2nd, journalists and members of other labour groups demonstrated outside the offices of El Jareeda newspaper in Khartoum, demanding full pay, and against the decision of the administration of the paper to dismiss several journalists for demanding money owed to them. [size=no report]

On September 2nd, armed pastoralists shot and wounded several farmers (three seriously) at El Jadeed (South Darfur, coordinates for Manawashi used at prec2). The farmers had been attempting to clear the pastoralists of their land.
On September 1st, supporters of RAC leader Musa Hilal called for his release at a demonstration at Misteriya, North Darfur. [size=no report]

On September 1st, IDP supporters of the major Darfuri rebel groups comprising the SRF demonstrated in El Fasher, North Darfur against the exclusion of rebel groups from the transitional government, and prevented an FFC-organised event at the football stadium from taking place. Note that one source says FFC leaders were 'attacked' by the demonstrators, though this is not elaborate upon (actor 1 coded as protesters pending further information). [size=no report]

On September 1st, Beni Amir protesters marching from Kassala (and who had driven from Aroma to Saukin, before continuing on foot) arrived in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for peaceful reconciliation following deadly clashes between the Beni Amir and Nuba refugees in the city over the past weeks. [size=hundreds]

On August 31st, Beni Amir protesters set off on a march to Port Sudan from Kassala, walking to Aroma (where vehicles collected them to transport them to Saukin). The demonstrators were calling for peaceful reconciliation following deadly clashes between the Beni Amir and Nuba refugees in the city over the past weeks. [size=hundreds]

On August 30th, SAP demonstrators gathered in Wad Medani, El Gazira to protest against the transportation union linked to the Bashir regime. Soldiers were reported to have beaten protesters, injuring four. [size=no report]
On August 28th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan, calling for peaceful coexistence in the city, and an end to racial and tribal discrimination. [size=no report]
On August 28th, demonstrators gathered in El Gedaref calling for peaceful coexistence in Port Sudan. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On August 28th, FFC-organised protests took place in Saraf Omra (North Darfur state), calling for Bashir-era doctors (accused of selling medicine illegally) to be prevented from returning to the hospital. [size=no report]
On August 28th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala (Kassala state), calling for the provision of basic health services in the Khatamiya neighbourhood. [size=no report]

On August 28th, demonstrators gathered at Karari bus station (coded as Khartoum at prec2), calling for peaceful coexistence in Port Sudan, and an end to racial and tribal discrimination. [size=no report]

On August 28th, demonstrators gathered outside the courthouse in Omdurman, calling for justice for Ahmed El Kheir (who was tortured to death in Kassala on Feb 2nd). Police fired tear gas and live rounds at the protesters, and several lawyers were prevented from accessing the trial of the victim's alleged killers. [size=large]
On August 28th, demonstrators barricaded roads and set fire to tires in Burri in eastern Khartoum, following water shortages and power outages. [size=no report]

On August 27, clashes flared up once more in Port Sudan, involving the Beni Amar and IDPs from the Nuba mountains. One person was reported to have been killed in the violence, and a number of buildings torched.
On August 27th, retired police officers demonstrated in Khartoum, following the stoppage of their pensions. [size=no report]
On August 27th, students of the Shambat campus of the University of Khartoum demonstrated against the indefinite suspension of classes announced by the University. [size=no report]

On August 27th, teachers demonstrated in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), following the appointment of Bashir-era officials in the state ministry of education. The protesters called on the governor to remove the Director-General who appointed them, and to repeal the appointments. [size=dozens]

On August 27th, students demonstrated at El Razi University in Khartoum, following the suspension of three students, and calling for Bashir-era University directors to be replaced. Students also demonstrated at Wadi El Nil University, calling for the director to be replaced. [size=no report]

On August 27th, the Sudanese Artists Association demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for Bashir-era staff of the judiciary to be removed; for justice for the victims of violence during the national uprising; and in support of nominated judicial candidates for cabinet positions. [size=small]

On August 25th, ongoing clashes in Port Sudan between the Beni Amar and IDPs from the Nuba mountains continued. There are no reports of injuries or fatalities but several homes were reported to have been torched.
On August 25th, demonstrators gathered in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), demanding an end to the violent clashes which have rocked the city in past days. [size=no report]

source: Radio Dabanga; Al Rakoba; Sudan Tribune
notes: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.
On August 24th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala, calling for federal intervention to address the violence in Port Sudan. [size=no report]
On August 24th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum, calling for federal intervention to address the violence in Port Sudan. [size=no report]

source: Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
notes: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.

source: Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune; Al Rakoba
notes: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.
On August 22nd, supporters and relatives of detained paramilitary leader Musa Hilal demonstrated outside of the Sudanese Professional's Association in Khartoum, calling for his release. [size=small]

On August 22nd, family members and friends of some of those killed in the course of the national uprising gathered at the army HQ in Khartoum to commemorate the death of their loved ones. [size=dozens]

source: Sudan Tribune; Al Rakoba; Radio Dabanga
notes: From August 21st to August 24th, intercommunal clashes occurred between Beni Amir forces and a Nuba militia, comprised of armed IDPs, in Port Sudan in unclear circumstances. 37 people were killed (including an Imam, on Aug 24th), 126 injured (in addition to 3 injured SAF soldiers, coded as AssocActor1), and dozens of dwellings torched. The state governor has been removed and a state of emergency declared, with soldiers and RSF paramilitaries deployed to the city. Fatalities distributed across four events.

On August 21st, three armed men (suspected of being pastoralists) attacked three schoolgirls who were farming near Teiga IDP camp (South Darfur state, coordinates used at prec2). Two of the victims escaped, the other was repeatedly raped.
On August 20th, demonstrators gathered in Kassala, in protest of the high bread price. [size=no report]

On August 20th, armed pastoralists attacked displaced farmers at an unspecified location between Turmo and Tur IDP camp (Central Darfur state, coordinates for Tur used at prec2). One person was injured, and second was wounded but died at a hospital in Nietiti the following day.

On August 20th, a large group of farmers from Zamzam IDP camp were fired upon by unknown gunmen, after they refused instructions by police and the chief of the area to return to the camp. Nobody was injured in the gunfire, which occurred in the vicinity of Abu Delek (North Darfur state).

actor2: UNISFA: United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (2011-)
notes: On August 19th, armed youths attacked a UNIFSA patrol (who appear to have been attempting to also arrest a suspect) at Dari market in the Northern Sector of Abyei (coordinates for Diffra, Abyei area, used at prec2). One peacekeeper was injured and a Misseriya man killed during the clash.
On or around August 19th, demonstrators gathered in Jabal Aulia (Khartoum state), in solidarity with those missing from the June 3rd massacre in Khartoum. [size=no report]

On August 19th, attackers (implied to be armed pastoralists from Aroul settlement) attacked two civilians at a farm at Kumbo Kesri (Central Darfur state, approximate coordinates 10km from Mukjar used at geoprec2). One teenage girl was killed, and her mother seriously injured.

On August 19th, residents of Port Sudan (Red Sea state) blocked the road to Saukin following an attack by SAF soldiers on a family at their home. The protesters agreed to disperse when Military Intelligence officials agreed to find the perpetrators. [size=large]

On or before August 19th, SAF soldiers stormed a house in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), beating and threatening its inhabitants and wounding several (including a child), and then looted money and belongings from the dwelling.

On August 18th, two teenage boys were killed when unexploded ordnance detonated at a farm in Murnei locality (West Darfur state, coordinates used at prec2). Their 19 year-old sister lost her hand in the explosion.

On August 18th, armed pastoralists attacked Hajjaj village near Tunjur (North Darfur state, coordinates for Tunjur used at prec2), wounding one civilian. The attackers were involved in an attack on nearby Taradona village the same day, where they claimed to be searching for stolen animals.

On August 18th, armed pastoralists attacked Taradona village (North Darfur state), abducting eight civilians (who were retrieved by security services the following day). The attackers claimed to be looking for stolen animals.
On August 18th, four armed pastoralists abducted a farmer at Fanga (Central Darfur state). There is no further information.
On August 17th, protesters from East Darfur demonstrated in Khartoum, calling for jailed paramilitary leader Musa Hilal to be released. [size=no report]

On August 17th, IDPs from Zamzam camp demonstrated against the power-sharing agreement reached between the TMC and FFC, on the grounds that it does not sufficiently address the problems associated with war in Darfur. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
notes: On August 17th, military intelligence officers detained three civilians (including one teacher) at Fanga (Central Darfur state), claiming that they had stolen a missing weapon. The three were tortured by officers whilst in detention.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On August 17th, RSF paramilitaries attacked civilians at Fanga (Central Darfur), killing three and wounding two, according to SLM-Al Nur rebels.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Rapid Support Forces
actor2: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On August 17th, the final documentation of the power-sharing agreement and Constitutional Declaration were signed at a ceremony in Khartoum, initiating the new transitional government. Executive and legislative organs are to be appointed and instituted over the coming weeks. UPDATE: On Aug 21st, the Sovereign Council was appointed, comprising five members of the military, five members of the FFC, and a civilian agreed upon by both. Lt. Gen Abdel Fattah al-Burhan has become president.

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On August 15th, men wearing RSF uniforms and riding camels (Note: the source describes the attackers as armed pastoralists in RSF attire) attacked a group of farmers near Katur (North Darfur state). After firing in the air, they then beat the farmers with whips.

On August 14th, three armed pastoralists abducted and raped two female children (aged 14 and 11) as they worked on their farm near Abu Zerega (North Darfur state). The girls (one of whom is in a coma) were released the following day. A vigilante group arrested the attackers and handed them to the police.

source: Darfur Network for Monitoring and Documentation; Radio Dabanga
notes: On August 14, 2019, armed men in military uniform (coded as SAF) attacked farmers in the area of Kaag Kulli (South Darfur state), beating them and robbing them of property.

On August 12th, protesters (including IDPs) marched in El Fasher (North Darfur state), in protest at the killing of three farmers and wounding of one by pastoralists at Dolma on August 10th. [size=large]

On August 10th, approx. 20 armed pastoralists shot four farmers in the area of Dolma (North Darfur state, coordinates for Kabga used at prec2), killing three (update: the fourth farmer later died of his injuries on Aug 20th). The attack was in retaliation for the farmers moving animals belonging to the pastoralists to Shangil Tobaya police station, after they trespassed on their land.
On August 8th, armed pastoralists attacked and beat seven children at Dobo Umda (North Darfur state), and abducted two of those children.

On or around August 7th, employees of the Savings and Social Development Bank in Khartoum, and demonstrated against the reassignment of colleagues involved in anti-govt protests, and the for the director to resign. [size=no report]
On August 7th, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), in solidarity with the victims of an attack on protesters in Omdurman which killed 4 on Aug 1st. [size=no report]

From August 5th to 7th, striking doctors protested in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the new director-general of the state Health Ministry to be replaced by a figure untarnished by association with the Bashir regime, and for an improvement in their working environment. [size=small]

On or around August 7th, residents of Kalakla (Khartoum state) demonstrated at the locality office against the failure of authorities to prevent rain water from accumulating on streets in the area. [size=no report]
On or around August 7th, pastoralists demonstrated in Kassala (Kassala state) against the encroachment on pasture lands by farmers. [size=no report]

On or around August 7th, protesters from West Kordofan state gathered at the Ministry of Oil in Khartoum, demonstrating against the harmful effects of oil production in the area, and the lack of economic benefits to the public. [size=no report]

On or around August 7th, parents of university students gathered at the Ministry of Higher Education in Khartoum, to protest against admissions procedures for students who failed their secondary school exams. [size=no report]

From August 5th to 7th, striking doctors protested in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the new director-general of the state Health Ministry to be replaced by a figure untarnished by association with the Bashir regime, and for an improvement in their working environment. [size=small]
On August 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered at the electricity office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for an end to power outages in the city. [size=dozens]

actor1: SPLM-N-Abdelaziz: Sudan People's Liberation Movement (North) (Abdelaziz al-Hilu faction)
assoc_actor_1: BC: Beja Congress; SLFA: Sudan Liberation Forces Alliance
notes: On 6 August 2019, three rebel groups - including the SPLM-N faction headed by Abdelaziz al-Hilu, the Beja Congress - Corrective, and the SLFA - announced they were forming the United Sudanese National Congress alliance (aka 'Kush Alliance') [event coded to SPLM-North Abdelaziz HQ in Kauda, Heiban locality, South Kordofan state].
On August 6th, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum to express solidarity with the family of a boy killed by a stray bullet in Omdurman on Aug 3rd. [size=large]
On August 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered at the electricity office in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for an end to power outages in the city. [size=dozens]
On August 5th, demonstrators gathered in Dongola (Northern state), in protest at the killing of a protesters the previous day in the same town. [size=no report]

From August 5th to 7th, striking doctors protested in El Geneina (West Darfur state), calling for the new director-general of the state Health Ministry to be replaced by a figure untarnished by association with the Bashir regime, and for an improvement in their working environment. [size=small]

On August 4th, protesters gathered in Dongola (Northern state), in protests at the deterioration of electricity services in the city. Regular forces (coded here as SAF) fired live rounds at protesters, killing one. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
actor2: FFC: Forces for Freedom and Change
notes: On August 4th, the TMC and FFC signed the Constitutional Declaration, laying out an agenda for the transitional government, and paving the way for the establishment of its central legislative and executive institutions across various dates in late August. The agreement has been publicly rejected by the SRF, and the Sudanese Professionals Association has declined to participate in the power-sharing arrangements.
On August 3rd, security forces (coded here as police) fired at civilians celebrating the Constitutional Declaration in Omdurman. A stray bullet hit and killed a boy in his house.

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Khartoum and Khartoum North, as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. Security was heavy in the area, though no incidents have so far been reported. [size=very large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in Umm Rawaba (North Kordofan state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

On August 1st, demonstrators gathered in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre in the city on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. [size=large]

source: Guardian (United Kingdom); Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
notes: On August 1st, demonstrators (including students) gathered in Omdurman as part of a day of nationwide protests against the massacre at El Obeid on July 29th, and for justice for the victims of other acts of violence by state security organs during the course of nationwide protests. notes: On 3 June 2019, RSF, police and NISS (and possibly members of the army) cleared protesters at the sit-in in Khartoum (Khartoum, Khartoum) and killed at least 100 protesters (some of whom died later of their wounds), and injured around 700 (including at least 4 journalists, one of whom was shot and wounded). 70 rapes were also reported. 40 dead bodies were dumped into a river by RSF and found on June 4. Five women are still missing, as well as at least 15 others. RSF attacked students and security staff at the University of Khartoum, and looted the University. [size=no report]

On 3 June 2019, two communal militias (likely to be members of the Tama and Rizaygat, given their activity in the area) clashed at Hejlij in the Ed Daien area (East Darfur state), reportedly over control of land. 5 were killed and at least 15 wounded.

At an unspecified date (implied to be in late May or in the month of June, and coded as June 1st at time precision 3) 8 men and 9 children were abducted in central Abyei by suspected Misseriya and Nuer militiamen. 2 of the men were later found dead. At an unspecified time(s) in June (though implied to be early June, and coded as such), nine South Sudanese refugees were reported to have been killed in Omdurman. Additionally, there are reports of multiple rapes, seven injuries, and two missing persons. On May 7th, striking dock workers of the Sea Ports Corporation protested outside the offices of the company in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), to pressure the company to fulfil their promise to place temporary workers on permenant contracts, in a bid to resolve precarious employment practices at the port. [size=no report]

On May 7th, striking workers from the Kenana Sugar Company gathered outside the military garrison in Kenana (Sennar state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators vowed only to leave once labour conditions improved at the plant. [size=hundreds]

On May 7th and/or 8th, two South Sudanese Nuer clans (belonging to the Leek and Mayom sections) clashed in Khartoum using bladed weapons. Nine people were reported to have been killed (initial reports said one), and an unspecified number were injured. The violence is appartently linked to a revival of past greivance between the clans. Sudanese police have made a number of arrests.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019)
actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
assoc_actor_2: Journalists (Sudan); NCP: National Congress Party; Popular Security Forces (Sudan)
notes: During the week commencing May 6th, official forces made a number of significant arrests. On May 7th, the Transitional Military Council announced that former NISS director Salah 'Gosh' was under house arrest (following reports that he was free to move around Khartoum). On May 7th, RSF paramilitaries announced they had made a number of arrests following a raid on a house containing arms and explosives in Khartoum (with the military subsequently announcing that Popular Security paramilitaries were involved). On or before May 7th, 21 NCP officials were arrested as they tried to flee Nyala in South Darfur, whilst the Governor of North Darfur announced that NCP executives were being purged from the administration in the state. On May 7th, journalist Khalid Taha and activist Mohamed Burri were arrested outside the sit-in protest in Khartoum by unspecified security forces (actor 1 coded as Govt of Sudan; RSF; police; and NISS).

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Al Bisharayab (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Sinkat (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]

On May 6th, demonstrators gathered in Dinder (Sennar state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water; to denounce corruption among officials; and to call for the arrest of figures connected to the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On or around May 6th, SAF soldiers reportedly attacked protesters at the large sit-in protest outside the army HQ in Khartoum. Details are vague on the incident, though the source implies that a Captain of the Sudanese national football team was injured in the incident. [size=large]
On May 5th, a sit-in protest began in El Fula (West Kordofan state), as part of nationwide protests calling for a transition to a civilian govt. There is no further information. [size=no report]

On May 5th, demonstrators marched to the sit-in at Port Sudan (Red Sea state), to present a list of demands to the acting governor, which called for the removal of individuals linked to the Bashir regime from office. Soldiers initially prevented the demonstrators from reaching the sit-in, but later permitted them to proceed. [size=large]

On May 5th, demonstrators marched in Kassala (Kassala state), and presented a memorandum to the acting governor, calling for the Bashir regime institutions to be dismantled. Sources indicate that a sit-in protest began on or after this date. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Al Bisharayab (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]

On May 5th and 6th, demonstrators gathered in Sinkat (Red Sea state), to protest against a lack of basic services, food and water, and to call for the removal of some local officials. [size=no report]
On May 5th, nine SAF soldiers clashed with Falata pastoralists at Bashir Nugu (Blue Nile state), after the soldiers attempted to rob 500 sheep from them. Two Falata were killed in the exchange.

On May 5th, the market and electricity services of Abu Jubaiha (South Kordofan state) were destroyed in a fire. Supporters of the Alliance for Freedom and Changed accused 'shadow brigades' (paramilitary forces associated with Bashir's NCP regime) of being behind the fire, and denied that their own members were involved.

On May 5th, an army officer attempted to dismantled a barricade established by protesters at the sit-in in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). A group of demonstrators attacked the officer for attempting to do so. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Popular Security Forces (Sudan)
notes: On May 4th, IDPs from the Otash camp marched to the sit-in taking place outside the army base in Nyala. The IDPs were demanding improved rations and facilities in the camp. Security forces used tear gas and live ammunition against the crowds. One person was killed by gunfire and twenty wounded, and the sit-in appeared to be dispersed. [size=5,000]

On May 4th, IDPs from Otash camp marched in Nyala (South Darfur) in solidarity with the sit-in at Khartoum, calling for a transition to a civilian regime. The majority of the demonstrators were reported to be children and women. Disputed accounts of events have followed; doctors and opposition groups said that security forces (implied to be riot police, and coded as Police) attacked demonstrators with batons, tear gas and live rounds, wounding six (two with gunshot wounds) and arresting four. Authorities have accused the demonstrators of instigating the violence, saying that five police were wounded, who responded with tear gas. [size=5,000]
On May 3rd, residents of Teemteem village demonstrated following the rape of a 14 year-old girl the same day, and demanded that authorities do more to prevent such attacks. [size=small]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On May 3rd, RSF paramilitaries attacked miners at Atagula gold mine in Talodi locality (South Kordofan). Five sustained gunshot wounds, with one of the injured dying en route to the hospital in Aby Jubaiha. The source notes the mine has experienced problems relating to the presence of RSF soldiers, after the mine was purchased by a company belonging to RSF commander (and de factor VP of Sudan) 'Hemeti' last year.

On May 3rd, demonstrators continued their sit-in and closure of part of the Khartoum-Port Sudan highway at Suakin (Red Sea state). Soldiers fired above the heads of the demonstrators, in an unsuccesful bid to disperse them. [size=thousands]

On 3 May 2019, a pastoralist attacked a group of five girls close to Teemteem village (North Darfur). Four of the girls fled, though the assailant raped a 14 year-old girl. A group from the village apprehended the perpetrator, and took him to the police station at Kutum.

On May 2nd, protesters began a sit-in protest outside the army base in Nyala (South Darfur), which security forces attempted to disperse three days later (see separate event; note that the sit-in appeared to be continuing as of May 9th). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and in support of the sit-in taking place outside the army HQ in Khartoum. [size=no report]
On May 2nd protesters marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 2nd, multiple large demonstrations took place in Khartoum, with protesters calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=large]

actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On May 2nd, RSF paramilitaries and unspecified security services (coded as police, pending further information) attempted to break the sit-in outside the military garrison in Zalingei (Central Darfur). RSF paramilitaries fired live rounds, and hit a protester with their vehicle, causing several injuries. The security services also hit a protester with their vehicle, causing another injury. Following the attack, additional protesters joined the sit-in in solidarity, and another march was organised in the city. [size=large]
On May 2nd protesters marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 2nd protesters marched in Al Azazah (El Gazira state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]

On May 2nd, demonstrators gathered in Doka (Gedaref state), calling for individuals associated with the Bashir regime to be removed from office in the area. The protesters blocked roads (note that there is no indication that they barricaded roads, and actor 1 has accordingly been coded as Protesters), and searched vehicles headings towards the border crossing with Ethiopia, on suspicion that joint military patrols were carrying fleeing officials, before releasing the vehicles when it was determined they were not. [size=hundres]

On May 2nd protesters marched in Saukin (Red Sea state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change, and against the lack of basic services and food in the town. The demonstrators began a sit-in, closing part of the Khartoum-Port Sudan highway, and shutting down Suakin port. [size=hundreds]
On May 2nd protesters marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On May 2nd protesters marched in Singa (Sennar state), calling for a transition to civilian rule along the lines espoused by the Forces for Freedom and Change. [size=no report]
On or around May 1st, further marches were conducted in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the ongoing sit-in at the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On May 1st, demonstrators affiliated with the SPA marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur), to deliver a petition to the military garrison, before beginning a sit-in. The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for security organs linked to the Bashir regime to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On May 1st, protesters marched in Ed Damazin, in support of the sit-in protest taking place in the city, and on behalf of disabled groups who had joined the sit-in that same day. The demonstrators are calling for a transition to civilian rule in Sudan. [size=no report]

On May 1st, demonstrators marched in Doka (Gedaref state), against the failure of the governor to carry out their demands, including retaining personnel associated with the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On May 1st, demonstrators marched in Gedaref (Gedaref state), against the failure of the governor to carry out their demands, including retaining personnel associated with the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On May 1st, IDPs from Zamzam camp marched to the World Food Programme HQ in El Fasher (North Darfur), stating they had not received food rations for the past five months. The protesters then organised a sit-in demonstration outside the HQ. [size=no report]
On January 4th, protests occurred once more in Atbara (River Nile state). Unspecified security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas to disperse the crowds.

actor2: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Military Intelligence Service
notes: On May 1st, protesters gathered in Delling (South Kordofan state), calling for a transition to civilian rule. Soldiers from Military Intelligence attacked the demonstrators with batons, and made fifteen arrests, including of three of its leaders. [size=no report]

On May 1st, protesters gathered for a second time in Delling (South Kordofan), to demonstrate against a lack of water in the locality. The protesters handed a memorandum to the executive director of the locality offices. Note that this is a separate protest to the other protest that took place on the same day in Delling, but the source is unclear as to whether there was an overlap between those doing the protesting at the two events. [size=no report]

On April 30th, demonstrators marched in Berber (River Nile state), and staged a sit-in protest in the park. The demonstrators are admonishing the authorities to implement a list of demands made to the locality commissioner several days before, and in solidarity with the sit-in protest in Khartoum. [size=no report]

On April 29th, and in response to calls from the Transitional Military Council for demonstrators to cases occupying main roads and bridges, demonstrators built barricades around the main sit-in outside the army HQ in Khartoum, and burnt tires in the streets of Khartoum North. [size=no report]

On April 29th, and in response to calls from the Transitional Military Council for demonstrators to cases occupying main roads and bridges, demonstrators built barricades around the main sit-in outside the army HQ in Khartoum, and burnt tires in the streets of Khartoum North. [size=no report]
On April 28th, four marches were conducted in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the ongoing sit-in at the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On April 28th, four PDF paramilitaries raped two girls (aged 15 and 18) at a farm in Elfaid Um-Abdalla (South Kordofan, coordinates for Abu Kershola used at precision 2), and held their grandmother at gun point as they did so. The attackers then fled the scene, though the source suggests the police have not taken action to trace down the attackers.

On April 28th, protesters demonstrated at an unspecified location in Rashad locality (South Kordofan state; coordinates for Rashad used at precision 2), and delivered a memorandum to military command in the area. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for the security organs associated with the regime to be dismantled. [size=no report]

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); NUP: National Umma Party
notes: On April 27th, a small youth mob attacked a meeting of the Popular Congress Party in Khartoum. The source indicates the mob (which a PCP source described as chanting NUP slogans, as well as those in support of the Declaration of Freedom and Change (assoc actor 1 coded as NUP)) attacked the attendees due to the PCP's refusal to distance themselves from the NCP regime. 64 PCP members were injured, according to a PCP official. The military intervened to separate the groups, and then arrested 143 PCP members, before releasing them in the evening. [size=hundreds]
On April 26th, SPA members marched in Port Sudan, in support of the ongoing sit-in at the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

On April 26th, demonstrators gathered in Berber (River Nile state), and handed a list of demands to the locality commissioner, which called for accountability for violence committed against protesters, and for individuals associated with the Bashir regime to be removed from office. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for crimes against demonstrators to be investigated; and for state institutions to be purged of associates of the NCP regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators gathered in Nyala (South Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for political, social, and security institutions in the state which were linked to the NCP regime to be dissolved. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in Shendi (River Nile state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in Kosti (White Nile state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in Nouri (West Darfur state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, protesters gathered in El Managil (El Gazira state), and staged a sit-in protest. The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators marched in Umm Dukhun (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, IDP's marched in Garsila (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators marched in West Jagmha (Central Darfur; no geographic information found, coordinates for state capital Zalingei used at precision 2). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, IDP's marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, demonstrators marched in Mukjar (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, IDP's marched in Bindisi (Central Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 25th, a children's march was organised in Khartoum, in support of the ongoing sit-in outside the Military HQ in the city, which was also the destination of a large rally. Additionally, 40 judges attended the sit-in protest, signing a memorandum calling for a rapid transition to civilian rule. [size=large]

On April 24th, dock workers as well as custom officials marched in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), in support of the ongoing sit-in outside the Naval HQ in the city, and against precarious employment practices at the docks. The workers also announced a four day-long strike in support of the nationwide anti-govt demonstrations. [size= no report]

On April 24th, demonstrators marched in Tendelti (White Nile state), against the Bashir regime, and in favour of what the protesters described as the favour shown towards them on the part of the military. Residents of the town also protested against the lack of basic services and their need for food. [size=no report]

On April 24th, lawyers marched in El Fasher (North Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for corruption to be stamped out; and for effective justice mechanisms to be restored. [size=no report]

On April 24th three senior figures in the Transitional Military Council stepped down, following accusation that they were 'Islamists', heralding a shift in Sudanese politics, in which purges and crackdowns will be initiated against groups and individuals deemed to be 'Islamists'.

On April 23rd, demonstrators gathered in El Fula (West Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for the NCP paramilitary security forces to be dissolved in West Kordofan. [size=no large]

On April 22nd, demonstrators marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for justice for the victims of killings in El Gedaref towards the start of the national uprising. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the HQ of the Second Infrantry. [size=thousands]
On April 23rd, journalists demonstrated in El Fasher (North Darfur state), calling upon the acting governor to purge state institutions of corrupt individuals. [size=no report]

On or around April 23rd, IDP's demonstrated at an unspecified location(s) in Kass locality (South Darfur). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for those responsible for war crimes in Darfur to be held to account. [size=no report]

On April 23rd, demonstrators gathered in Foro Baranga (West Darfur), to stage a sit-in protest (lasting at least three days) outside the SAF headquarters. The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime; for perpetrators of abuses and war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted; and for paramilitary security organs to be dismantled. [size=no report]

On April 23rd, demonstrators (including IDPs) marched in Zalingei (Central Darfur state). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for those responsible for war crimes in Darfur to be held to account. [size=no report]

On April 22nd, demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur state) to protest the continued confiscation of their vehicles (which had been seized as part of a security sweep beginning last August, on the grounds that they were unregistered). The demonstrators said they had paid their fines, but the vehicles remained impounded. Customs officials claimed the matter was out of their hands, and was instead the responsibility of RSF paramilitaries. [size=dozens]

On April 22nd, three marches were organised by demonstrators in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

actor1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
notes: On April 22nd, six RSF paramilitaries accosted a Darfuri miner at Atagula gold mine in Talodi locality (South Kordofan). One of the RSF soldiers shot the miner dead, following a personal dispute with the man earlier that day. The source notes the mine has experienced problems relating to the presence of RSF soldiers, after the mine was purchased by a company belonging to RSF commander (and de factor VP of Sudan) 'Hemeti' last year.

On April 22nd, men in SAF uniforms (and coded as such) attacked Kumbur village in Nyukur payam (Southern Kordofan state, coordinates used at prec2), killing one civilian and looting 71 head of cattle.
On April 22nd, bank employees march in Khartoum, in support of the ongoing sit-in outside the Military HQ in the city. [size=hundreds]

On April 21st, demonstrators (including teachers and accountants) gathered in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters began a sit-in outside the Fourth Infrantry HQ. [size=no report]

On April 21st, demonstrators gathered in Singa (Sennar state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters either began a sit-in outside the 17th Infantry Division, or joined an existing one (note that the starting date of the sit-in is not specified). [size=no report]

On April 21st, demonstrators (including displaced persons from the Nuba Mountains) marched in El Obeid (North Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters began a sit-in outside the Fifth Infrantry HQ. [size=no report]

On April 20th and 21st, demonstrators marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for justice for the victims of killings in El Gedaref towards the start of the national uprising. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the HQ of the Second Infrantry. [size=no report]

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On April 21st, soldiers clashed with NISS agents who were retreating from El Leri (South Kordofan state), after NISS agents had been involved in clashes with PDF paramilitaries, and fired at protesters that same day. Four NISS agents were killed, and ten agents were wounded.

On April 21st, demonstrators gathered at the railway HQ in Atbara (River Nile state), in protest against the employment of corrupt officials at the company. The protesters then took control of a train, and took it to Khartoum the same day, with supplies for protesters at the sit-in at Khartoum. [size=hundreds]

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On April 21st, PDF paramilitaries clashed with NISS agents in El Leri (South Kordofan state), after NISS agents had shot at protesters the same day. Two NISS agents were killed, and four civilians were wounded.

On April 21st, six marches were organised by demonstrators in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the Naval HQ. [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On April 21st, demonstrators gathered in Kutum (North Darfur state). The demonstrators were calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. During the march, NISS agents fired upon the demonstrators with live rounds. At least 12 people were wounded (several seriously), though the governor of North Darfur said one of the wounded was a police officer (coded as assoc actor 2). The demonstrators then torched the NISS building, and attacked the house of a former local official (although there is no further information on this attack at present). [size=no report]

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On April 21st, protesters marched in El Leri (South Kordofan state). The demonstrators wanted the local military commander to cease gold production in the area, which they alleged was causing environmental damage harmful to human and animal life, whilst contributing nothing to the area. NISS agents were reported to have been opposed to the closure of the facility, and fired into the crowd, wounding five protesters. [size=no report]

On April 21st, demonstrators gathered in Babanussa (West Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for the NCP political and security apparatus to be dismantled in West Kordofan. [size=no report]

On April 20th and 21st, demonstrators marched in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for justice for the victims of killings in El Gedaref towards the start of the national uprising. After marching in the town, the protesters joined the sit-in protest outside the HQ of the Second Infrantry. [size=no report]

Between April 16th-20th, the Timen and Kolfan communities were reported to have clashed at unspecified locations near Habila and Dilling (Southern Kordofan state, coordinates used at prec2). During the violence, 17 were killed and 17 injured, property and livestock looted, and the village of Kalandi (no coordinates found) torched. Fatalities distributed through five days of clashes.

On April 19th, demonstrators gathered in El Fasher (North Darfur state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and for those responsible for war crimes in Darfur to be prosecuted at the ICC. The source notes that the demonstrators marched to a sit-in demonstration that was taking place, but does not specify how long the sit-in had been taking place for (one event coded, pending further information). [size=no report]

On or around April 19th, a sit-in protest began at An Nahud (West Kordofan state), which has continued for at least 10 days (as of April 29th). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

On April 19th, demonstrators gathered in El Daein (East Darfur state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. There is no further information on this protest. [size=no report]
On April 19th, demonstrators gathered in Nyala (South Darfur state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=no report]

Between April 16th-20th, the Timen and Kolfan communities were reported to have clashed at unspecified locations near Habila and Dilling (Southern Kordofan state, coordinates used at prec2). On April 18th, demonstrators gathered in Ed Damzain (Blue Nile state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime. [size=tens of thousands]

On April 17th, demonstrators gathered in Terter (South Kordofan state. Note that there are two locations called Tartar/Terter in South Kordofan; location in Habila locality used at precision 2). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and also for the release of prisoners detained in Gedaref during recent protests. [size=no report]

On April 17th, demonstrators gathered in Al Abbasiya (South Kordofan state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and also for the release of prisoners detained in Gedaref during recent protests. [size=no report]

On April 16th and 17th, demonstrators continued their sit-on protest outside the Second Infrantry HQ in El Gedaref (Gedaref state). The demonstrators are calling for a civilian government to be formed, to replace the Bashir regime, and also for the release of prisoners detained in Gedaref during recent protests. assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
source: Radio Dabanga; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune; Africa Confidential
notes: On April 11th, elements of the Sudan Armed Forces announced a coup against President al Bashir, suspending the constitution and establishing a nationwide ceasefire, whilst declaring a new state of emergency and curfew (the coup itself may have taken place on the evening of the 10th). The presidency switched hands from Lt Gen Ahmed Awad Ibn Auf to Lt Gen Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Burhan between April 11-12th after protests over a two-year military government. RSF paramilitary leader Lt Gen Mohamed Hamdan ('Hemeti') was appointed interim vice-president on April 13th. After the coup, Bashir was placed under house arrest (and then moved to Kober prison on the 16th), a number of his aides as well as senior NCP figures (including the new interim NCP leader, Ahmed Haroun) were arrested, the Army Chief of Staff Kamal Abdel-Marouf was relieved and NISS director Salah 'Gosh' was forced to step down. On April 17th, the military announced that irregular forces (described as Popular Defence, and Popular Police, in the source) were being integrated in the mainstream armed forces; on April 24th three senior figures in the Transitional Military Council stepped down, following accusation that they were 'Islamists'.

Several soldiers sustained cuts in the battle, which was used to identify six soldiers who were later arrested.

source: International Crisis Group; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
notes: On Feb 25th, President Bashir issued five decrees, one of which banned protests and public gatherings, and another which granted sweeping powers to search and arrest to security forces. Hundreds were reported to have been arrested under the measures by the end of the week. Additionally, decrees were issued targetting those hording goods, as well as on financial transactions.

On 24 February 2019, large numbers of demonstrators gathered in multiple parts of Greater Khartoum (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman), as part of nation-wide anti-government protests. Police and unspecified security services (actor2 coded as police) dispersed protesters via beatings, and made a number of arrests. Security services used live ammunition in Omdurman, wounding three protesters (one of whom was shot in the head). Students also protested, and security services were reported to have fired tear gas into at least one campus (either in Khartoum or Omdurman). [size=large]

Students from the University of Medicine and Technology were reported to have been forced to leave the University premises, and several students were filmed being beaten by security services. Additionally, sescurity services were reported to have fired tear gas into at least one campus experiencing protests on that day (either in Khartoum or Omdurman). [size=large]
