On Feb 22nd, anti-government protests broke out in Sugdan (Northern state; no geographical information found, coordinates for Dongola used at precision 3), as part of nationwide anti-government protests. Security forces (coded here as police) used tear gas and sticks to disperse the demonstrators.
On the morning of Feb 22nd, multiple anti-government protests were held in Khartoum (coded as a separate event to the evening protests in the city).

On Feb 22nd, multiple demonstrations occurred in the evening in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum, and Khartoum North), in response to the announcement of a one year-long state of emergency by President Bashir that evening.

source: Radio Dabanga; BBC News; Radio Tamazuj; Sudan Tribune
notes: On Feb 22nd, President Bashir announced that a one year-long state of emergency was being introduced (on March 11th, this was revised to six months); that legislation permitting him to run for re-election had been postponed; and that he dissoled his cabinet whilst removing all state governors. Defence Minister Awad Ibn Ouf was announced as the new Vice-President the following day, the former governor of Gazira state - Mohamed Tahir Eila - became the new Prime Minister; seven new ministers were later appointed on 1 APril. New governors are all from military, intelligence and/or police backgrounds. On 26th Feb, Bashir reshuffled the senior commanders of the Sudan Armed Forces (though retained the Chief of General Staff), and announced a new Minister of Defence. On Feb 28th, controversial former governor of North Kordofan - Ahmed Haroun - (who is indicted by the ICC in connection with war crimes in Darfur) was appointed interim Chairman of the NCP, after President Bashir stepped down from the role.

On the morning of Feb 22nd, anti-government protests were held in Omdurman (coded as a separate event to the evening protests in the city). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas, which was also fired into a mosque.

On Feb 22nd, multiple demonstrations occurred in the evening in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Omdurman, Khartoum, and Khartoum North), in response to the announcement of a one year-long state of emergency by President Bashir that evening. In Khartoum, a doctor's residence was stormed by an unspecified security force (coded here as police), who fired tear gas into the residence, and arrested a doctor.

On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). In addition, protesters (including students) demonstrated against the privitisation of the port in the city. Security forces (coded here as police) dispersed demonstrators using tear gas, and used 'excessive violence' against protesters.
On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Arbaji (El Gazira state).
On Feb 21st, a number of anti-government protests took place in the Greater Khartoum area (coded as three events in Khartoum, Burri, and Omdurman).

On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Atbara (River Nile state).

On Feb 21st, a pastoralist militia attacked a group of women who were collecting firewood close to Mashrou Abu Zeid, east of Dubo El Omda (North Darfur, coordinates used). One woman was wounded by gunfire (which hit her in the hand), and another woman was hit in the head with an axe. There is no clear motivation for the attack.

On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Wad Medani (El Gazira state). Six people were reported to have been injured after unspecified security forces (coded here as police) attacked them with tear gas and batons.

On Feb 21st, two groups of porters (reported to be Nuer and Ngok Dinka) clashed in Amiet market in Abyei, under unclear circumstances. One person was killed, and 23 were injured. UNIFSA peacekeepers separated the groups, and one was injured in the process.
On Feb 21st, anti-government protests took place in Sennar (Sennar state).

On January 13th, demonstrators marched in Amri (Northern state) as part of nation-wide protests. Protesters also demanded the release of a local teacher who had been arrested prior to the march.
On January 13th, police dispersed protesters in Sennar (Sennar state), using batons and tear gas.

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On 13 January 2019, NISS agents arrested three civilians (including a doctor) in Nyala. They were brought to the NISS facility, and were tortured and humiliated alongside people who had been arrested during an anti-government demonstration.

On January 13th, protests occurred once more in Khartoum. Police were reported to have used 'excessive force' against protesters, and fired tear gas into a school, injuring a number of students. Note that at an unspecified time in the week beginning January 13th three South Sudanese civilians were killed at a protest in Khartoum. Three fatalities have been recorded for this event, although there is no information on the precise day that they were killed, nor of the circumstances.

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 13th, security agents (coded here as NISS) raided a house in the Burri neighbourhood of Khartoum, beating one man, and detaining twenty others.
On January 13th, police dispersed protesters in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), using batons and tear gas. A number of arrests were made.
On January 13th, protests broke out in Khartoum North. Police beat demonstrators, and used tear gas and live rounds against the protesters, and made a number of arrests.
On January 13th, demonstrations were reported in El Gedaref as part of nationwide protests.
On January 11th, demonstrators gathered in Bara (North Kordofan), as part of nation-wide protests. Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and what the source describes as 'excessive force'.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Atbara (River Nile state) as part of nationwide protests.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Omdurman following Friday prayers as part of nationwide protests.

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 11th, NISS agents detained a number of people (the source suggests these were primarily students) in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile), after allegedly setting up a fake call for protests on social media, in order to arrest any who showed up.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Khartoum following Friday prayers as part of nationwide protests. Police dispersed protesters using tear gas.
On January 11th, protesters gathered in Rabak (White Nile state), and were dispersed by police using tear gas and batons.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Khartoum following Friday prayers as part of nationwide protests. Police dispersed protesters using tear gas.
On January 11th, demonstrations broke out in Kassala (Kassala state) as part of nationwide protests.

source: Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga; Sudan Tribune
notes: On 9 January 2019, during large protests in in Omdurman (Um Durman, Khartoum), the police entered a hospital and used tear gas in the building, wounding a number of doctors. The police also targeted and injured protesters. [size=large]

source: Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj; Radio Dabanga
notes: On 9 January 2019, large demonstrations broke out in Omdurman (Um Durman, Khartoum), leading to a violent response by multiple branches of the security service (including police, army, NISS, and RSF, with masked plain-clothes agents also said to be active (the latter coded as UAG)). Three protesters were shot dead, whilst police injured an unspecified number with tear gas and live ammunition (police reports indicate a minimum of twelve were injured). A number of people were also arrested. [size=large]
On January 9th, protests occurred in the Burri district of Khartoum, prompting police to fire tear gas at the demonstrators.

On January 9th, protesters gathered again in Atbara (River Nile state), before being dispersed by police using tear gas and what the source describes as 'excessive force'. Dozens were reported to have been arrested.

On January 9th, around 100 lawyers gathered in Nyala (South Darfur) to demonstrate their opposition to the NCP government, and the violent handling of nation-wide protests. Several lawyers were arrested by unspecified security forces after the protest (coded here as Police).

On January 8th, large demonstrations were reported in El Gedaref (Gedaref state) against the NCP government, and calling for those responsible for deaths of protesters in the town in December to face justice. Police and unspecified security forces used tear gas and 'excessive violence' against the protesters.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 8th, protests spread to Abri (Northern state). Police used batons and tear gas to disperse the crowds, wounding three. The following day, NISS agents arrested a number of demonstrators, as well as an activist. Note that RSF paramilitaries have been reported to have arrived in the town.
On January 8th, protesters gathered again in Atbara (River Nile state), before being dispersed by police using tear gas.

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 7th, protesters gathered once more in Port Sudan (Red Sea state). Police used tear gas, batons, and a water cannon against the demonstrators, before detaining dozens of protesters.

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 7th, protesters gathered inside and around the Grand Bosque in the Burri district of Khartoum. NISS agents fired tear gas into the mosque, and were reported to have shot and wounded a protester.

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 7th, demonstrations - led by secondary school students - occurred once more in Atbara (River Nile state). As the demonstrators marched, police 'confronted' demonstrators with batons and tear gas.
On January 6th, very large demonstrations were reported in Wad Madani (El Gazira state). Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and batons, and arrested an unspecified number.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019); Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces; Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services; Unidentified Armed Group (Sudan)
assoc_actor_2: Journalists (Sudan); PCP: Popular Congress Party; Teachers (Sudan)
notes: During the week beginning January 6th, numerous arrests were made by security services in the midst of nation-wide demonstrations, with the Interior Minister stating on Jan 7th that 817 had been arrested (the opposition NUP has provided a figure of around 2,000). In addition to various post-demonstration arrests, 20 professors from the University of Khartoum and 3 journalists were arrested in Khartoum (coordinates used) on Jan 6th; an MP with the PCP was reportedly detained on Jan 9th, after she participated in a demonstration in Omdurman. Elewhere, an activist was rearrested in El Gedaref on January 8th, prompting a social media campaign calling for his release, whilst a nurse (who is also an activist) was arrested in El Obeid on Jan 9th.

On January 6th, large demonstrations occurred in Khartoum, involving several processions of protesters coordinating their actions (note the demonstrations were called for by the Sudanese Professional Association). Police prevented protesters from marching to certain parts of the city, and dispersed the protesters (though the source does not specify how).

On January 6th, demonstrations occurred once more in Atbara (River Nile state). Ther demonstrations were said to be large in size, and were dispersed by police using tear gas. Police also detained an unspecified number of protesters.

On January 4th, demonstrations resumed in Omdurman after Friday prayers. The demonstrations were reported to have experienced lower levels of attendance than in previous protests, though several hundred worshippers were reported to have attended. Riot police dispersed the protesters using tear gas.

On January 4th, demonstrations resumed in Khartoum after Friday prayers, in several parts of the city. The demonstrations were reported to have experienced lower levels of attendance than in previous protests.
On January 4th, demonstrations resumed in Khartoum North after Friday prayers. The demonstrations were reported to have experienced lower levels of attendance than in previous protests.

actor1: SLM/A-Nur: Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (Abdul Wahid al-Nur Faction)
notes: On January 4th, SLM/A-al Nur rebels clashed with SAF soldiers at Boulay (Central Darufr). The source indicates there are fatalities, though does not specify a number (3 fatalities coded).
On January 3rd, demonstrations occurred in Port Sudan (Red Sea state), which were reported to have been violently dispersed by police, including a 'heavy' use of tear gas.

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On 2 January 2019, NISS agents arrested a student who had participated in a demonstration earlier that day in Khartoum, beating him, before taking him to a detention centre in Mayo (southern Khartoum), where he was also beaten by NISS agents.

actor2: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: On January 2nd, a peaceful demonstration was reported to have taken place in El Gandoul square in Khartoum. Security agents (coded here as NISS) arrested three civil society activists.

On January 1st, several hundred demonstrators were reported to have marched in Medani (El Gazira state; note that the source states the protests were in 'Mandani', though there is no location matching this name. Coordinates for Wad Medani used on the assumption that this is a typo).
